questions.text: Which of the following is included in pre-embryonic phase of development?
questions.solution:
The pre-embryonic phase includes the first 2 weeks of intrauterine development, from fertilization to the formation of bilaminar germ disc. 

Major morphogenetic events that occur in the pre-embryonic phase include:

  1. Fertilization
  2. Cleavage
  3. Transportation of cleaving zygote
  4. Formation of blastocyst
  5. Implantation
  6. Specialization of primordial embryonic tissue
  7. Differentiation of embryoblast to bilaminar germ disc
  8. Differentiation of trophoblast to cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast

Related Pearl: Timeline of Various Events Occurring during the Pre-embryonic Phase Development (1st two weeks)

Event

< 24 hrs

Zygote is formed; cleavage begins immediately

2–3 days

5–8 cell stage

3–4 days

Stage of compaction and formation of morula with 16 cells

4–5 days

questions.text: What does the inner cell mass form during blastocyst formation?
questions.solution:
The inner cell mass gives rise to the embryoblast, which forms the embryo proper.

Around the 4th-5th day of development, the morula becomes the blastocyst. Fluid passes into the morula from the uterine cavity and converts it to a blastocyst with a fluid-filled cavity called blastocoele. This fluid partially separates the cells of the inner cell mass from the outer cell mass.

Cell masses in the blastocyst:

  • The outer cell mass is called the trophoblast and forms a major part of the placenta
  • The inner cell mass is called the embryoblast and forms the embryo proper

questions.text: Which of the following germ layer(s) are formed from the epiblast?
questions.solution:
Epiblast gives rise to all the 3 germ layers through the process of gastrulation. 

After the formation of the primitive streak, the epiblast cells migrate toward the primitive streak. When they arrive at the primitive streak, these cells become flask-shaped, detach from the epiblast, and slip beneath the primitive streak. This inward movement is known as invagination.

Some of the invaginated epiblast cells displace the hypoblast to create the embryonic endoderm. Endoderm is the first germ layer to form. 

Some of the invaginated cells then start occupying the space between the epiblast and newly created endoderm to form mesoderm. Cells remaining in the epiblast then form the ectoderm. 

The image given below shows the formation of germ layers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the wall of the veins?

choices.text: It is thinner than that of the arteries
The tunica adventitia is thicker than the tunica media
The tunica media contains a lesser quantity of collagen than in arteries
The amount of elastic tissue or of smooth muscle is much less, than the arteries

questions.solution:
Option c is false: The tunica media of the veins contains larger quantities of collagen than that of arteries.

The structure of veins differs from that of arteries as follows:

  • The wall of a vein is thinner than that of an artery having the same sized lumen.
  • The tunica media contains a much larger quantity of collagen than in arteries, whereas the amount of elastic tissue or of muscle is much less.
  • Due to the above reasons, the wall of a vein is easily compressed and after death veins are usually collapsed. By contrast, arteries retain their patency.
  • The tunica adventitia of veins is thicker than the media (especially in large veins).
  • In some large veins such as inferior vena cava, the adventitia also contains some muscle and elastic fibers.
  • In small veins, the tunica intima, media and adventitia cannot be distinguished from each other.

 

The image below shows illustrations comparing the structure of wall of an artery (a) and that of a vein (b). The H&E stained micrograph (c) shows an artery and a vein.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the term osteoid?

choices.text: Gelatinous matrix and inorganic mineral salts

questions.solution:
During the formation of bone, the mesenchymal cells and osteoblasts secrete type I collagen and gelatinous matrix (unmineralized bone matrix), which together forms the osteoid.

The collagen fibers swell up within the gelatinous matrix and become indistinct. Calcium salts are deposited into the gelatinous matrix under the influence of osteoblasts and this process is called mineralization.

The below image shows the microscopic appearance of osteoid in a patient with osteoid osteoma.

questions.text: In which of the following types of cartilages is type 1 collagen present?
questions.solution:
Type I collagen is present in fibrocartilage.

  • Fibrocartilage (also known as white fibrocartilage) contains both type I and type II collagen. 
  • Hyaline and elastic cartilage contains only type II collagen

questions.text: A detective is brought to the casualty with an upper eyelid laceration following a knife fight. The plastic surgeon palpates for a landmark to administer lignocaine before suturing. Where is the local anesthetic injection given?
questions.solution: Upper eyelid lacerations are sutured under supraorbital nerve block. The anesthesia is achieved by approaching the nerve at the supraorbital foramen/notch. The supraorbital notch is present at the junction of lateral two-third and medial one-third of the supraorbital margin (point C). It transmits the supraorbital nerve and vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves provides sensory innervation to the scalp?

choices.text: Anterior division of greater auricular nerve

questions.solution:
The lesser occipital nerve provides sensory innervation to the scalp.

  • Anterior to ear and vertex: Branches of the trigeminal nerve branches and facial nerve.
  • Posterior to the ear and vertex: Spinal nerves

Sensory innervation of the anterior and posterior scalp is shown in the image below:

The temporal and posterior auricular branches of the facial nerve constitute the motor supply to the anterior and posterior scalp, respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following branches of the external carotid artery is not given off in the carotid triangle?
questions.solution:
The posterior auricular artery, maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery are branches of the external carotid artery which are not given off in the carotid triangle.

The external carotid artery gives off 5 branches in the carotid triangle. They are:

  • Anterior branches:
    • Superior thyroid artery
    • Lingual artery
    • Facial artery
  • Medial branch - Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Posterior branch - Occipital artery 

The image given below shows the carotid triangle and the branches of the external carotid artery within it.

questions.text: A dentist provides local anesthesia by injecting lidocaine at the site marked X to block a division of the trigeminal nerve. Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the trunk of this nerve?
questions.solution:
The site marked X is the mandibular foramen which contains the inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve. All the muscles mentioned above are supplied by the trunk of mandibular nerve except the lateral pterygoid. The lateral pterygoid is supplied by the anterior division of mandibular nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone and paliperidone have the highest risk of galactorrhea.

The adverse effect occurs due to their higher D2 blocking potency.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply to the muscle marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution: The muscle marked in the image is the teres major and it is supplied by the lower subscapular nerve.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man had recently joined a gym to improve his physical health. He attempted to lift a 30 Kg dumbbell but developed sudden pain in his right arm. He came to the casualty with an abnormal bulge over his arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following tendons is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Popeye sign, which is seen in the proximal biceps tendon rupture.

Popeye sign is seen on flexing the elbow. An extremely prominent bulge of the muscle belly occurs as its unrestrained fibers contract.

The proximal biceps tendon makes up 90-97% of all biceps tendon ruptures. In isolation, it has little effect on the upper limb function but produces a characteristic deformity called the Popeye sign.

Note:

The 4 most common areas of tendon rupture include quadriceps, achilles, rotator cuff (most commonly supraspinatus), and biceps.

questions.text: Angiography of the upper limb vessels in a patient shows a blockage in the brachial artery. All of the following vessels will have decreased flow, except:
questions.solution:
The anterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery. Hence, it is unlikely to have a decreased flow due to blockage in the brachial artery. 

The brachial artery has 3 branches: 

  • Profunda brachii (accompanies radial nerve in the spiral groove) gives off nutrient artery to the humerus and an ascending branch which anastomoses with posterior circumflex humeral artery. It then divides into: 
    • Anterior descending artery (Radial collateral artery)  
    • Posterior descending artery (Middle collateral artery) 
  • Superior ulnar collateral artery (accompanies ulnar nerve)
  • Inferior ulnar collateral (supratrochlear) artery

The image given below shows branches of the brachial artery.

questions.text: The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The femoral nerve is split into the anterior and posterior divisions by the lateral circumflex femoral artery.

The course of femoral nerve is given below:

  • Arises from posterior division of ventral rami of L2-L4 spinal segments on the posterior abdominal wall
  • Enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament
  • In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath
  • Divided into anterior and posterior branches by lateral circumflex femoral artery

Note: Obturator nerve is divided into anterior and posterior divisions by obturator externus in the upper part and adductor brevis in the lower part.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot?
questions.solution:
Tibialis posterior tendon is the most medial structure passing through the canals in the flexor retinaculum of the foot.

The flexor retinaculum of the foot converts grooves on the tibia and calcaneus into canals for the tendons. The structures passing through canals formed by flexor retinaculum are as follows: (from medial to lateral)

  • Tendons of tibialis posterior
  • Flexor digitorum longus
  • The posterior tibial vessels
  • The tibial nerve
  • The tendon of flexor hallucis longus

questions.text: The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to:
questions.solution:
The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to the iliotibial tract of the fascia lata.

Origin:

  • Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium, posterior to posterior gluteal line
  • Posterior superior iliac spine
  • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
  • Sacrotuberous ligament.

Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.

Action:

  • Major extensor of hip joint
  • Lateral rotation of hip joint
  • Active in powerful abduction of thigh

Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

Note:

The fascia lata is a deep fascial investment of the whole thigh musculature.

The iliotibial tract is a longitudinal thickening of the fascia lata, which is strengthened posteriorly by fibres from the gluteus maximus.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy with shortness of breath was diagnosed with chronic inflammation of conducting airways. Which of the following is not a feature of the affected structure?

choices.text: Includes first 16 generations starting from trachea
Secrete variety of molecules that aid in lung defence
Membrane bound organelles namely lamellar bodies are present

questions.solution:
Chronic inflammation of conducting airways is suggestive of asthma. Lamellar bodies are storage bodies of surfactant present in the alveoli and not the conducting airway.

The conducting airways form the first 16 generations from the trachea to the terminal bronchial. It is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. It also consists of smooth muscles which are responsible for bronchoconstriction and dilatation. It also consists of other specialized cells such as:

  • Basal cells - stem cells
  • Clara/Club cells - specialized epithelial cells (non-ciliated cuboidal cells) that:
    • Functions as stem cells
    • Helps in lung defense.

The conducting airways secrete several substances that in lung defense such as:

  • Secretory immunoglobins - IgA
  • Collectins - surfactant protein(SP)-A and SP-D
  • Defensins
  • Reactive oxygen species
  • Reactive nitrogen species.

questions.text: The rate of inspiration is controlled by _______

choices.text: Ventral group of neurons in medulla

questions.solution:
The rate of inspiration is controlled by the pneumotaxic center.

Pneumotaxic centre:

Location: Upper pons (dorsally in nucleus parabrachialis)

Function:

  • Transmits signals to the inspiratory area, i.e., it inhibits the apneustic center and thus the dorsal respiratory group of neurons, to stop inspiration. 
  • It thus helps limit duration of inspiration and switching between inspiration and expiration.
  • This has a secondary effect of increasing the rate of breathing because limiting the duration of inspiration also shortens the duration of expiration, and hence, the entire period of respiration.

questions.text: Which of the following do not stimulate either central or peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Hypercapnia is a stimulus for central and peripheral chemoreceptors and not hypocapnia.

Option b: The peripheral chemoreceptors are stimulated by hypoxia (hypoxic, stagnant and histotoxic but NOT anemic hypoxia)and exercise (increased K+ levels).

Option c: The central chemoreceptors are stimulated by hypercapnia and resultant acidosis.

Option d: Low perfusion pressure produces hypoxia because the amount of O2 delivered to the receptors per unit time is decreased. This stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors.

questions.text: Thin filaments consists of all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin.
    • Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along the tropomyosin molecules.
    • Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
      • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
      • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
      • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

questions.text: Which among the following is embryologically and physiologically unrelated to other neural cells?
questions.solution:
Microglia are physiologically and embryologically unrelated to other neural cell types. They arise from macrophages outside the nervous system.

Related Pearl: Glial cells and their functions

Scavenger cells that remove debris resulting from injury, infection, and disease.

Astrocytes :

  • Fibrous – in white matter
  • Protoplasmic – in grey matter

Astrocytes form the tight junctions making blood–brain barrier

Produce substances that are tropic to neuron

questions.text: Where does the initiation of nerve impulse occur in a spinal motor neuron?
questions.solution:
In a spinal motor neuron, initiation of nerve impulse occurs in the axon hillock and initial segment of the axon because it has a very high density of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Hence, this region is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential.

Parts of a Neuron:

  • Cell body/perikaryon: contains many Nissl bodies.
  • Dendritic zone where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated.
  • Axon hillock: part of the cell body from which the axon arises.
  • Initial segment: the first part of the axon where propagated action potentials are generated.
  • An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings. The unmyelinated regions of a myelinated axon are termed as nodes of Ranvier.
  • Synaptic knobs/nerve endings where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters.

Note: Action potentials are generated at the initial segment in spinal motor neurons and the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding smooth muscle is false?

choices.text: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential
Dense Bodies are present instead of Z lines
It can exert a variable tension at any given length
Sympathetic stimulation produces excitatory membrane potentials

questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation (norepinephrine) of a smooth muscle produces inhibitory potentials and relaxation.

Parasympathetic stimulation (or acetylcholine) causes depolarization and contraction in the smooth muscle.

Smooth muscle can be divided into:

  • Unitary smooth muscle - has low-resistance gap junctions between individual muscle cells and functions in a syncytial manner
  • Multiunit smooth muscle -  made up of individual units with few or nil gap junctions.

Blood vessels have both unitary and multiunit smooth muscle in their walls.

Option A: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential with continuous irregular contractions independent of its nerve supply. This state of partial contraction is called tonus or tone.

Option B: Dense bodies are present instead of Z lines in smooth muscle. These are bound to actin filaments by α-actinin.

Option C: Smooth muscle can exert variable tension at any given length. This property is called plasticity. When a unitary smooth muscle is stretched, it first exerts increased tension. However, if it is held at this length after stretching, the tension gradually decreases. This is referred to as plasticity.

questions.text: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to influx of ______
questions.solution:
Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of chloride ions (Cl-).

If, binding of a neurotransmitter causes the postsynaptic membrane to become more negative (hyperpolarized), it is called an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) because hyperpolarization moves the membrane potential farther from the threshold and makes the cell less likely to reach an action potential.

IPSP may be due to :

  • Increase in Cl- influx. This action causes diffusion of negatively charged chloride ions from outside the postsynaptic neuron to the inside, thereby carrying negative charges inward and increasing the negativity inside. This leads to hyperpolarization.
  • Increase in K+ efflux. This action causes positive ions to diffuse to the exterior, which causes increased negativity inside the neuron, which leads to hyperpolarization.
  • Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following structures regulates the sleep-wake cycle?
questions.solution:
The hypothalamus and several non-specific nuclei in ascending reticular activating system (ARAS) located in the midbrain are involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Sleep Centres

Stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and promotes the waking state. 

The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the raphe nuclei of ARAS is rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce wakefulness.

The cholinergic neurons in the pontine reticular formation, on stimulation, induce sleep.

Stimulation of the histaminergic neurons of the posterior hypothalamus produces arousal. 

Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep. This sleep-inducing effect is thought to be mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons.

Orexin produced by hypothalamic neurons also appears to have a role in sleep-wake transition by regulating the changes in activity in these brainstem neurons.

wakeful state  Sleep 
Norepinephrine  Acetylcholine 
Serotonin  GABA 
Histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with slow-wave sleep?
questions.solution:
In slow-wave sleep, (Stages 3 and 4 of NREM) delta waves predominate the EEG.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: The type of potentiation in hippocampus is ______
questions.solution:
Long-term potentiation occurs in the hippocampus.

LTP is a rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron.

NMDA receptors are involved in LTP.

questions.text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by ______.
questions.solution:
Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. 

Pacinian corpuscle is the most sensitive mechanoreceptor in the somatosensory system. It is responsive to high-frequency (30–500 Hz) vibratory stimuli and pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Option A: Merkel's disc sense touch and sustained pressure. They are slow adapting receptors. Present in epidermis.

Option B: Meissner's corpuscle sense tap and flutter. They are present in dermal papillae. They are rapidly adapting receptors. 

Option D: Ruffini endings sense skin stretch and fluttering vibration.

The following image shows Merkel's disc and Meissner's corpuscle being more superficial (reponsive to touch) than Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscle (which are deeper in the dermis and responsive to pressure).

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: Which of the following are climbing fibers?
questions.solution:
Climbing fibers are olivocerebellar fibers. They originate from the inferior olivary nucleus. 

Climbing fibers and mossy fibers are the two main excitatory inputs to the cerebellum.

Climbing fibres Mossy fibres
They come from one single source via the inferior olivary nuclei. They come from many sources and the fibers synapse with granule cells to form glomeruli.

End on single Purkinje cells.

Convey proprioceptive inputs from all over the body.

 Axons of granule cells bifurcate and form parallel fibers which excite multiple Purkinje cells.

Note: Mossy fibres provide direct input via the pontine nuclei.

questions.text: Insulin mainly facilitates glucose uptake in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Insulin mainly stimulates glucose uptake by skeletal muscles.

Glucose uptake by skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and adipose tissues is via GLUT-4 which is insulin-dependent. In the presence of insulin, GLUT-4 receptors translocate to the cell membrane and hence, glucose uptake by the cell occurs. 

Most of the other GLUT transporters are not insulin sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. Ex: GLUT-1 in RBCs, brain and kidneys. (GLUT-3 is also present in the brain and kidneys)

Note: Insulin promotes glucose uptake in the liver. However, this is done by increasing the activity of glucokinase and inactivating glycogen phosphorylase. The net effect is the synthesis of glycogen and decreased breakdown of glycogen.

questions.text: A patient with a known brain tumour learns that his pituitary stalk has been affected. Secretion of which of the following hormones is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk?
questions.solution:
The secretion of prolactin is increased after the sectioning of the pituitary stalk. 

Prolactin is unique among the pituitary hormones because the predominant central control mechanism is inhibitory, i.e., dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion. Hence, sectioning of the pituitary stalk (Ex: In head trauma or compressive skull lesions) prevents this inhibition and leads to increased secretion of prolactin. 

Note:

If the pituitary stalk is cut above the pituitary gland but the entire hypothalamus is left intact, the posterior pituitary hormones (ADH & Oxytocin) show a transient decrease because they are initially synthesized in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and are then transported down to the nerve endings to the posterior pituitary gland, requiring several days to reach the gland.

questions.text: Dicrotic notch is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Dicrotic notch is caused by closing of aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve shuts.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an endopeptidase?
questions.solution:
Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, not endopeptidase.

Peptidases (proteases) are of two types:

  • Endopeptidases - they act at interior peptide bonds in the peptide molecules. Ex- pepsin, trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase.
  • Exopeptidases - they hydrolyze the amino acids at the carboxyl ends of the polypeptides, one at a time. Ex- carboxypeptidase, aminopeptidase.

questions.text: The step involving which of the following enzyme is reversible in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, which is a reversible step of glycolysis.

The irreversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate kinase

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. Further examination shows generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy is shown in the given image. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly, along with muscle biopsy showing vacuoles are suggestive of Pompe's disease. 

Pompe's disease (type II glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a mutation in alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme. A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes of peripheral, voluntary muscles and progresses to involve the cardiac muscle and diaphragm. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), cardiomyopathy, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. Myozyme 

The treatment for Pompe disease is recombinant enzyme alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme), which can prevent worsening or reverse cardiac and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms. Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.

No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

The flowchart given below depicts fructose metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following ETC complexes does not pump hydrogen ions?
questions.solution:
Complex II does not pump any proton.

ETC complexes:

  1. Complex I pumps 4 protons
  2. Complex II doesn’t pump any proton
  3. Complex III pumps 4 protons
  4. Complex IV pumps 2 protons

questions.text: Hyperammonemia inhibits the TCA cycle, by depleting levels of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Hyperammonemia results in the depletion of alpha-ketoglutarate.

This happens in two steps:

  1. The excess free ammonia binds to glutamate and forms glutamine.
  2. To compensate for the reduced glutamate, alpha-ketoglutarate is aminated to glutamate.

Thus, hyperammonemia eventually depletes alpha-ketoglutarate, leading to a stoppage of the TCA cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cofactor of the enzyme alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate is not a cofactor of the enzyme alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.

Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase enzyme complex has 5 coenzymes, They are :

  • Lipoate
  • Thiamine pyrophosphate
  • NAD+
  • FAD
  • Coenzyme A

All the enzymes carrying out oxidative decarboxylation require these 5 coenzymes, namely:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase, catalyzing the reaction Pyruvate to acetyl CoA
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase

questions.text: Amino acids absorb UV light due to _____.
questions.solution:
Amino acids absorb UV light due to aromatic ring. Aromatic amino acids such as tryptophan, tyrosine, and phenylalanine absorb 250 to 290 nm UV light. The maximum absorption of UV light is by tryptophan.

Compound Wavelength absorbed
Aromatic Amino acids 250-290 nm (UV)
Nucleotides (pH=7) 260 nm (UV)
Porphyrins 400 nm (Soret band, visible)

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is involved in the process of oxidative deamination?
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is involved in the process of oxidative deamination.

In contrast to transamination (transfer amino groups), oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase results in the liberation of the amino group as free ammonia. Glutamate dehydrogenase can use NADH or NADPH during oxidative deamination.

The image below shows oxidative deamination by glutamate dehydrogenase:

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of  5- hydroxy indole acetic acid seen?
questions.solution:
Excessive urinary excretion of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is seen in carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is marked by symptoms of bronchospasm, cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. It occurs due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism by tumors commonly in the small intestine, liver and lungs. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA.

questions.text: Defect in the metabolism of which of the following is associated with increased cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
Defect in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids (homocysteine) due to the deficiency of cystathionine-β-synthase leads to homocystinuria and increases cardiovascular risk.

Homocysteine is highly cytotoxic and elevated levels within the bloodstream are believed to damage the endothelial lining of arterial vessels, leading to intravascular coagulation.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids do not participate in the formation of an alpha helix?
questions.solution:
Proline does not participate in the formation of an alpha helix. 

The stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from hydrogen bonds formed between the oxygen of the peptide bond carbonyl and the hydrogen atom of the peptide bond nitrogen of the fourth residue down the polypeptide chain. Since the peptide bond nitrogen of proline lacks a hydrogen atom, it is incapable of forming a hydrogen bond with carbonyl oxygen.

questions.text: The two nitrogen atoms in urea are derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The two nitrogen atoms in urea are derived from ammonia and aspartate.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which is the rate-limiting enzyme in beta-oxidation of fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-1 (CPT-1), is the rate-limiting enzyme in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

CPT-1 is responsible for transferring the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine which can enter the outer mitochondrial membrane. Thus the acyl group enters the mitochondria from the cytoplasm.

Malonyl CoA is an inhibitor of CPT-I. Thus,

  • In the fed state, with high insulin: glucagon ratio, acetyl CoA carboxylase is active and malonyl CoA is produced, which inhibits β-oxidation.
  • In the fasting state, with low insulin: glucagon ratio, acetyl CoA carboxylase is inactive and malonyl CoA is not produced. Hence, β-oxidation takes place.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of glycosphingolipid ?
questions.solution:
Glycerol is not a component of glycosphingolipids. 

Glycolipids or glycosphingolipids are complex lipids that contain the alcohol sphingosine instead of glycerol. They also contain a fatty acid and a carbohydrate attached to sphingosine. 

Glycosphingolipid = Sphingosine + fatty acid + carbohydrate

questions.solution:
For transketolase reaction, the coenzyme is thiamine.

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in the following:

  • Transamination

  • ALA synthase

questions.text: What is the substrate for cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA by a long pathway that may be divided into five steps

  • Synthesis of mevalonate from acetyl-CoA
  • Formation of isoprenoid units from mevalonate
  • Condensation of six isoprenoid units form squalene
  • Cyclization of squalene to give rise to the parent steroid, lanosterol
  • Formation of cholesterol from lanosterol.

All tissues containing nucleated cells are capable of cholesterol synthesis, with the majority produced in the liver and intestine.

Related Pearl: Cholesterol synthesis

questions.text:
A 33-year-old with a large dirty wound on his knee and abrasions on his palms presents to the casualty. He does not remember the last time he received a TT injection and was thus given tetanus immunoglobulin. Which of the following is false about this type of immunity?

TT- Tetanus Toxoid
questions.solution:
Giving pre-formed immunoglobulin (e.g. Tetanus immunoglobulin) directly is an example of passive immunity, which is not long-lasting. 

The differentiating features between active and passive immunity:

Active Immunity

Passive Immunity

Actively produced by the host’s immune system

Passively received by the host

Induced by infection or immunogens

Readymade antibody is transferred

Immunological memory present

No memory 

Immunity is effective after a lag period or latent period

Immediate immunity

Broad specificity

Narrow specificity

A negative phase may occur 

No negative phase. 

Booster effect on subsequent dose

The subsequent dose is less effective

Secondary type response seen 

No secondary type of response

More effective

Less effective 

Long-lasting (Years)

Short-lasting (Days to weeks)

Example: Vaccines

Example: Antisera 

Negative phase: It is the time period during which the level of measurable immunity is lower than it was before the antigenic stimulus. This is because the antigen combines with any pre-existing antibody and lowers its level in circulation. It is seen at the beginning of the active immune response.

Secondary type response: If an individual who has been actively immunized against an antigen experiences the same antigen subsequently, the immune response occurs more quickly and abundantly than during the first encounter.

Related Pearl: Innate and Adaptive Immunity

Innate immunity

Adaptive immunity

Immediate maximal response

Lag phase between exposure and maximal response

Non-specific

Highly pathogen-specific

Limited diversity

Extensively diverse

No memory

Memory present

Subsequent exposure → Amplified response

Receptors: Pattern-recognition receptors

Receptors: T-cell and B-cell receptors

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a fever of 103°F, hypotension, confusion, and a diffuse rash as shown below. 3 days back, she had uncontrollable epistaxis for which a nasal pack was placed. What is the likely mechanism of action of the microbial toxin that has caused her current illness?
questions.solution:
This woman presented with fever, hypotension, and a diffuse erythematous rash, three days after a nasal packing was done. This is characteristic of toxic shock syndrome - commonly caused by staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens act by causing polyclonal activation of T cells. They activate a large number of T cells irrespective of their antigen specificity.

In contrast to regular antigens which bind to the binding groove on T cells, superantigens bind outside the groove directly to the lateral aspect of the TCR β chain. This leads to a massive release of cytokines and polyclonal activation of T cells.

Clinically, this manifests as fever, hypotension, and skin exfoliation.

Examples of organisms that produce superantigens:

  1. Bacterial
    • Staphylococcus aureus- Enterotoxins
    • Group A streptococci - Pyrogenic exotoxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis- mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  2. Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
    • Rabies nucleocapsid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  3. Fungal- Malassezia furfur

questions.text: You are counseling a new mother about the importance of breastfeeding. What forms the secretory component of the antibody that is maximally present in breast milk?

choices.text: Epithelial cells of lining mucosa only

questions.solution:
The antibody maximally present in breast milk is IgA. The secretory component of IgA is formed by epithelial cells of lining mucosa.

IgA occurs in two forms- serum IgA (monomer) and secretory IgA. 

Secretory IgA is a dimer formed by two monomer units joined together by a J-chain and a secretory component (secretory piece). Secretory IgA along with the J chain is synthesized by the plasma cells situated near the mucosal or glandular epithelium. The secretory component is synthesized by epithelial cells, not by plasma cells. 

It is believed to protect IgA from denaturation by bacterial proteases.

questions.text: The chromosome involved in DiGeorge syndrome is ________
questions.solution:
Chromosome 22 is involved in DiGeorge syndrome 

DiGeorge syndrome (Thymic hypoplasia) is the most common microdeletion syndrome characterized by low copy repeats and the deletion which occurs near the middle of the chromosome 22.

  • It is a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • It leads to aplasia and hypoplasia of thymus and parathyroid glands.
  • It is usually associated with Fallot’s Tetralogy and other anomalies of heart. Neonatal tetany is also seen.

Image: A child with DiGeorge syndrome, showing characteristic facial appearance, with tubular nose and carp-shaped (fish-like) mouth.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about severe combined immunodeficiency disorders?

choices.text: Reticular dysgenesis of de Vaal is a mild form of combined immunodeficiency
They are inherited as autosomal dominant disorders
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities
The defect in Swiss type agammaglobulinemia is at the level of multipotent hemopoeitic stem cell

questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities.

Severe combined immunodeficiency disorders are associated with severe deficiency of both humoral and CMI. They are inherited in both X-linked and autosomal recessive modes. There are different forms of this disorder: 

  • Reticular dysgenesis is the most serious form of combined immunodeficiency. Here the defect is at the level of the multipotent hemopoietic stem cell.
  • Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is associated with enzyme deficiency. The condition is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities which can be discerned radiologically.
  • Swiss-type agammaglobulinemia is associated with lymphocytopenia and severe defect in CMI. The basic defect is at the level of the lymphoid stem cell.

questions.text: You are observing flow cytometry being performed at a laboratory for MHC class 1 antigen. Identify the cells that lack this antigen.
questions.solution:
Red blood cells are anucleated cells that lack MHC class I antigens.

MHC class I antigens are present on platelets and all nucleated cells, except sperm cells. They are responsible for the presentation of peptide antigen to CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC), or the HLA complex, is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc. HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. The genes are clustered in three regions named MHC region-I, II and III.

MHC class II antigens are present only on antigen-presenting cells (macrophages, dendritic cells, B cells). They present the peptide antigen to CD4 T cells. APCs also contain MHC class I antigens. 

MHC region III comprises of genes that code for complement factors like C2, C4, C3 convertase, factor B and properdin, heat shock protein, tumor necrosis factor and steroid 21-hydroxylases.

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: Immune interferon is secreted by _______ ?
questions.solution:
Immune interferon or interferon gamma is secreted by Activated T lymphocytes.

Interferons (IFNs) are a group of signaling proteins produced and released by host cells in response to the presence of several pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, parasites, and also tumor cells.

Interferons are classified into three types:

  • Alpha Interferon (Leukocyte interferon) is produced by leucocytes. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Beta Interferon (Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Gamma Interferon (Immune interferon), is produced by T-lymphocyes. It is concerned with immuno-modulatory and anti proliferative functions.

questions.text: Wheal and flare are seen in ______ hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.solution:
Wheal-and-flare reaction is an example of Type I (immediate) hypersensitivity reaction.

Wheal and flare reaction

  • It is a skin eruption that occurs after an injury or injection of an antigen. It is characterized by swelling and redness caused due to the release of histamine.
  • The reaction usually occurs in three stages,
    • Erythema
    • Flare
    • Wheal

Wheal reaction

questions.text: By which of the following mechanisms is penicillin resistance commonly transferred to Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.solution:
Penicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is determined by plasmids that are most commonly transferred by transduction.

Penicillin resistance in Staphylococci most commonly occurs due to bacterial production of beta-lactamase, which inactivates penicillins by splitting their beta-lactam ring. These enzymes are inducible and are plasmid-mediated. They confer resistance to penicillin G, ampicillin, piperacillin etc. 

The genetic transfer of antibiotic resistance can occur in the following ways:

  • Transformation: After death or cell lysis, some bacteria release their DNA into the environment. Other bacteria, generally of the same species, can come into contact with these free DNA fragments, take them up and incorporate them into their DNA by recombination.
  • Transduction: This method involves the transfer of DNA, episome or plasmid from one bacterium to another with the use of a bacteriophage.
  • Conjugation: This mechanism requires the presence of a special plasmid called the F plasmid that codes for the sex pilus. It is the most common method of transfer of antibiotic resistance in most other bacteria.

Note: Change in penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) and production of β-lactamases are modes of penicillin resistance seen in S. aureus but the question asks for methods of transfer of drug resistance.

World Antibiotic Awareness Week 2019 is marked from November 18 to 24, aims to increase awareness of global antibiotic resistance and to encourage best practices among the general public and health workers to avoid the further emergence and spread of antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: What is the Lancefield grouping of β-hemolytic-streptococci based on?
questions.solution:
Lancefield grouping of β-hemolytic-streptococci is based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall. He classified them into 20 serological types from Group-A to Group V except for I and J.

Group A β-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified by Griffith typing based on protein antigens (M, T, R) present on the cell surface.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can survive up to 60°C, is PYR positive, and can grow on media with  6.5% NaCl?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Enterococcus feacalis can survive up to 60°C, is PYR test positive, and can grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl.

Enterococci have the following features:

  • Formation of tiny deep pink colonies on MacConkey’s medium
  • Survives at 600C for 30 minutes.
  • Growth in the presence of 40 % bile, 6.5% sodium chloride at pH 9.6.
  • PYR (Pyrrolidonyl Arylamidase) positive
  • Esculin hydrolysis is positive.
  • Usually nonhemolytic, but may show α or β hemolysis.

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes is a delicate organism, easily destroyed by heat (54°C for 30 min), PYR positive.

Option B: Streptococcus agalactiae is PYR test negative.

Option D: Streptococcus pneumoniae are readily destroyed by heat (52°C for 15 min).

questions.text: A patient presents with a laceration over his leg following trauma with an unclean sharp metal rod 3 days ago. He also complains of difficulty in opening his mouth and abdominal cramps. Microscopy of the wound discharge revealed rod-shaped bacilli with terminal spherical spores. Which of the following is the organism most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of tetanus caused by Clostridium tetani. It is a gram-positive, slender bacillus that has a spherical and terminal spore, giving it a characteristic drumstick appearance.

The genus clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.

Classification of Clostridium based on shape and position of spores:

  • Central or equatorial:  Clostridium bifermentans
  • Subterminal: Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  • Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped ): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficile
  • Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani

The below image shows the characteristic drumstick appearance of C. tetani.

questions.text: An old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells, and culture on MacConkey agar showed the following. Which organism is involved here?
questions.solution:
This patient who presented with dysuria and frequent micturition with urinalysis showing pus cells, and growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggests a diagnosis of urinary tract infection by Escherichia coli. 

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

  • Lactose fermenters - Escherichia, Klebsiella
  • Late lactose fermenters - Shigella sonnei
  • Non-lactose fermenters- Salmonella species, Shigella species

The image below shows lactose fermenting and non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

Mnemonic to remember non-lactose fermenters: (SPY PSM)

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia- late fermenter
  • Shigella (except S.sonnei which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding E. coli?

choices.text: Infectious dose of E. coli O157:H7 is 10^6 organisms

questions.solution:
Uropathogenic Escherichia coli strains characteristically possess fimbria such as mannose-resistant fimbria and P fimbria (named so as it binds the blood group P antigen.)

About Other Options:

  • Option a: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) is non-invasive.
  • Option b: Infectious dose of E. coli O157:H7 is very low (<10 organisms), whereas infectious dose for other variants of E. coli is very large (106–108 organisms).
  • Option d: Hemorrhagic-Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

questions.text: A child presents with profuse, painless diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows the following finding. What is this characteristic appearance called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae.  The image shows the characteristic fish in stream appearance of Vibrio.

Other options:

Options A and B: School of fish appearance and railroad appearance are shown by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D: Drumstick appearance is shown by Clostridium tetani due to its spherical and terminal spores.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas resembles that of _________.
questions.solution:
The action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is similar to that of the diphtheria toxin.

Both exotoxin A and diphtheria toxin cause ADP ribosylation of EF-2 and inhibit protein synthesis. Exotoxin A is a single-chain polypeptide with A and B fragments. The B fragment binds the toxin while the A fragment inactivates EF-2 in the presence of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD). This leads to the inhibition of polypeptide chain elongation and thus, protein synthesis. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding glanders disease?

choices.text: Strauss reaction is diagnostic of Glanders disease.
Acute glanders is characterized by serous nasal discharge.
Mallein Test is used for diagnosis of Glanders disease.
Human infection cannot be acquired from infected animals.

questions.solution:
Mallein Test is used for diagnosis of glanders disease.

Mallein test is a hypersensitivity test to the bacterial protein of Burkholderia mallei. Animals suffering from the glanders develop delayed hypersensitivity to the bacterial protein.

Other options:

Option A: Strauss reaction is not diagnostic of glanders, as in addition to B. mallei, it may also be produced by inoculation of other bacteria such as Brucella species, Preisz-Nocard Bacillus, Actinobacillus ligniersi, and Burkholderia pseudomallei.

Option B: Glanders disease may be acute or chronic. In acute glanders, there is fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration. The fatality rate is high.

Option D: Human infection is occupational and it occurs in ostlers, grooms, and veterinarians. Human infection is acquired from infected animals.

questions.text: A 18-year-old man presents with fever, diarrhea, and jaundice. He gives a history of consuming food at a roadside stall. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the etiological agent?

choices.text: It is transmitted by feco-oral route
A formalin inactivated vaccine is used for prevention

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of viral hepatitis which is most likely to be Hepatitis A. Hepatitis A virus belongs to the family Picornaviridae. It is transmitted by fecal-oral route and most of the infections are symptomatic.

There is no definitive treatment, thus, only supportive therapy is given.

A safe and effective vaccine named HAVRIX is available to prevent hepatitis A infection. It is a formalin-inactivated, alum-conjugated vaccine.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic requesting an HIV test. He had unprotected sexual contact with another man 3 weeks ago. Antibodies against which of the following will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot?
questions.solution:
Antibodies against gp41 will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot. 

Antibodies to HIV usually appear within 3–6 weeks of primary infection. The appearance of HIV-binding antibodies occurs prior to the appearance of neutralizing antibodies. The only viral proteins that elicit neutralizing antibodies are the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41.

The order of appearance of antibodies is as follows:

Antibody to envelope gp41 > Antibodies to gag protein (p24 and p55) > Antibodies to envelope gp120 > Antibodies to gag protein p17 > Antibodies to pol gene products (p31 and p66).

Note: The earliest antigen to appear in the blood following HIV infection is p24.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Marburg viruses?

choices.text: Marburg disease is a hemorrhagic disease
Person to person transmission is not seen
Investigation of choice is reverse transcription PCR
Filoviruses are categorized as World Health Organization (WHO) Risk Group 4 Pathogens

questions.solution:
• Person to person transmission is seen in Marburg disease.
  • Marburg virus disease (MVD) (formerly known as Marburg hemorrhagic fever) is an illness which is caused by Marburg virus begins abruptly, with a severe headache and severe malaise.
  • Many patients develop severe hemorrhagic manifestations between days 5 and 7, and fatal cases usually have some form of bleeding, often from multiple sites.
  • The current methods of choice for the diagnosis of filovirus infection are reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction and antigen capture ELISA for the detection of filovirus genomes and filovirion components.
  • All work with material suspected of containing filoviruses should be conducted only in maximal containment, i.e., in biosafety level 4 laboratories. The proper authorities and WHO reference laboratories should be contacted immediately when filovirus infections are suspected.

questions.text: In a patient with MCV of 109 fl, which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
MCV >100 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia which is not seen in anaemia of chronic disease. RBCs in anemia of chronic disease are initially normocytic and normochromic, becoming microcytic and hypochromic over time.

Vitamin B12 deficiency, thiamine deficiency, and orotic aciduria cause macrocytic anaemia.

questions.text: All the following statements are true about iron storage except that ______.

choices.text: In the liver, most ferritin is stored within the parenchymal cells.
In spleen and the bone marrow, iron is found mainly in macrophages.
Iron in macrophages is derived from the breakdown of red cells.
Hepatocyte iron is derived mainly  from hemoglobin.

questions.solution:
Hepatocyte iron is derived from plasma transferrin.

The storage form of iron is ferritin. The free iron is highly toxic, so it has to be sequestered to either ferritin or hemosiderin. In the liver, most ferritin is stored within the parenchymal cells; in other tissues, such as the spleen and the bone marrow, it is found mainly in macrophages. Hepatocyte iron is derived from plasma transferrin, whereas storage iron in macrophages is derived from the breakdown of red cells.

Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, wherein partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin. Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause intravascular hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Thalassemia causes extravascular hemolysis.

Causes of intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura ) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn 
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - Clostridial sepsis

Causes of extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia

Causes of both intravascular and extravascular:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia

questions.text: What is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ankyrin is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis (HS).

The chief protein component of the RBC membrane skeleton is spectrin. It consists of two polypeptide chains, alpha and beta. These dimers associate with actin oligomers. The spectrin–actin skeleton is then connected to the cell membrane by two distinct interactions.

  • Ankyrin and band 4.2 binds spectrin to the transmembrane ion transporter, band 3
  • Protein 4.1 binds the tail of spectrin to the transmembrane protein glycophorin A

Defect in any of the components of the red cell membrane skeleton results in hereditary spherocytosis. The image given below shows the pathogenesis of this condition.

Note: Few one-liners on membrane skeleton -

  • Most abundant integral proteins - glycophorin, band 3 
  • Responsible for biconcave shape of RBC - spectrin
  • Most severe deficiency - spectrin
  • Hereditary elliptocytosis is due to deficiency of alpha spectrin
  • Mushroom cells appearance due to deficiency of band 3
  • Never involved in HS - glycophorin

questions.text: Peripheral smear of a patient with viral hepatitis is given below. Which of the following statements is false about this finding?

choices.text: These are seen in G6PD deficiency
They are due to denaturation of globin chains
They are plucked out by macrophages in the spleen
They do not cause intravascular hemolysis

questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies which are dark stained inclusion bodies in red cells. They can cause intravascular as well as extravascular hemolysis.

In G6PD-deficiency, the RBCs are exposed to high levels of oxidants. This causes cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. The globin chains become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These can be detected by supravital staining.

Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis.

As RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen, the macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies. As a result, some of these partially devoured cells retain an abnormal shape i.e. as if a bite was taken out of them. Such cells are called bite cells. Bite cells are trapped in splenic cords and removed by phagocytes leading to extravascular hemolysis.

The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: Which of these histopathological findings would you not expect to see in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pseudo–Pelger–Huet cells are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and not Pelger–Huet cells.

Pelger–Huet cells are seen in Pelger–Huet syndrome, which is due to mutations in the lamin B-receptor gene. It is a neutrophil differentiation disorder with leukocyte appearance as:

  • Dumbbell-shaped bilobed nuclei
  • Reduced number of nuclear segments
  • Coarse clumping of the nuclear chromatin

In MDS, pseudo-Pelger Huet cells are seen due to abnormal nuclear budding i.e. neutrophils with only 2 nuclear lobes.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with generalized itching and mild hypoaesthesia of the skin. On examination, maculopapular patches were seen on her back. Biopsy revealed the presence of atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the dermis and epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given pathological feature is characteristic of a Pautrier's microabscess. These are seen in mycosis fungoides.

It is a mature, cutaneous, CD4+ T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Skin lesions include truncal scaling, red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules. Lesions may evolve into a systemic lymphoma, with visceral and nodal spread.

Sezary syndrome is a variant of mycosis fungoides. It is the leukemic seeding of blood by malignant T cells from the skin (CD4+). It presents with diffuse erythroderma and scaling. 

Histological hallmark includes:

  • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
  • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
  • Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.

The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.

questions.text: All are examples of elastic arteries except the _______.
questions.solution:
Coronary arteries are examples of muscular arteries.

Arteries are divided into three types according to their size and structural features:

Large or elastic arteries

Aorta, the major branches of the aorta (the innominate, subclavian, common carotid, and iliac arteries), and the pulmonary arteries

Medium sized or muscular arteries

Smaller branches of the aorta (e.g., the coronary and renal arteries)

Small arteries (≤2 mm in diameter) and arterioles (20 to 100 µm in diameter)

Vessels within tissues and organs

questions.text: Which of the following causes aneurysm formation due to defective elastin?
questions.solution:
Loeys–Dietz syndrome leads to aneurysm formation due to defective elastin (due to a defect in TGF-β signalling pathway).

Ehlers–Danlos syndrome Synthesis of type III collagen in some subtypes

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset blindness. He gives a history of frequent headaches along the sides of his scalp. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell / temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery.

It can also affect:

  • Ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent permanent blindness.

questions.text: What causes tigered myocardium?
questions.solution: Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fatty change. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating with normal myocardium.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome 3 months ago and had been started on a course of oral prednisolone. During the current visit, no improvement is noted with regards to facial puffiness and urine analysis reveals grade 3 proteinuria. Mutations in all of the following are associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. It can be caused due to mutations in the following components of the glomerular filtration barrier:

  • Nephrin, podocin - are molecular components of the slit diaphragm complex
  • Alpha-actinin 4 - is a component of the foot process cytoskeleton

Megalin is not a component of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is present in proximal convoluted tubular cells. Mutations in megalin may lead to some proteinuria but not nephrotic syndrome because glomerular filtration of proteins is not affected.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lying unconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for the following findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?

BUN - 60mg/dl

S. creatinine - 3.2mg/dl

S. potassium - 7mmol/L

ABG - high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Urine analysis - calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs).

Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens.

Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by:

  • Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin
  • Exogenous agents:  Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents

questions.text: A pathologist noted the following microscopic finding while examining a slide of a kidney. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

Option A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis.

Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates.

Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.

questions.text: All of the following lesions are proliferative breast lesions without atypia except:
questions.solution:
Duct ectasia is a non-proliferative breast change.

Radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, and florid hyperplasia belong to proliferative breast lesions without atypia.

Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and are not commonly found to have genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but unlikely to be true precursors of carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man who developed myocardial infarction 3 days ago now presents with jaundice. Lab investigations done are given below. Which region of the liver lobule is most likely affected here?

Bilirubin: 3 mg/dL

ALT: 1250 IU/L

AST: 1050 IU/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatocellular injury due to ischemia. Zone 3 (centrilobular zone) of the liver is most susceptible for ischemia because this zone is the farthest from the blood supply.

On the basis of blood flow, liver parenchyma can be divided into three zones. Zone 1 is closest to the blood supply and zone 3 is the farthest. They are:

  • Zone 1 - Periportal (around portal triad)
  • Zone 2 - Midzonal parenchyma
  • Zone 3 - Centrilobular (around hepatic vein)

A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below.

Note: Zone most susceptible to toxin damage is zone 1.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with nausea and upper abdominal pain. He experiences vague discomfort mostly in the afternoon and night, which is relieved by food. The urea breath test is positive. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a small ulcer with a clean base in the duodenum. From which of the following sites should the biopsy be taken to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of H. pylori gastritis. The preferred site for biopsy is the antrum as H. pylori are most often found in the antrum of the stomach.

H. pylori display tropism for gastric epithelia and are generally not found in the duodenal epithelium. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis may extend to involve the body and fundus, resulting in patchy mucosal atrophy.

The below image is a Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium of the antrum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?

choices.text: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
It is associated with the  deletion of chromosome 11p13
The most common presentation is hematuria

questions.solution:
Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13.

It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal mass.

Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features

  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome

  • Adrenal cytomegaly

  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: While undergoing a routine mammogram, a 45-year-old woman was found to have clusters of microcalcification in her right breast. A needle biopsy was done and revealed the following. Which of the following markers can be used to rule out invasive disease?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma.

DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the intact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography.

Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence the myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may be diminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules.

Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma, they are considered to be invasive carcinoma.

Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of metastases.
