questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months. Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolonged QT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy).

It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for defense against fungal infections.

It presents in childhood with the following features:

  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails)
  • Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as -
    • Autoimmune adrenalitis
    • Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
    • Idiopathic hypogonadism
    • Pernicious anemia 

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a combination of the following:

  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes

questions.text: You notice your senior performing a vagal maneuver in a stable patient with PSVT. Which of the following muscarinic receptors mediate the therapeutic effect of this maneuver?
questions.solution:
In vagal maneuver, the parasympathetic nervous system mediates activity on the heart via the M2 muscarinic receptor (most predominant subtype).

The receptors in the autonomic nervous system (ANS) are of 2 types:

  • Muscarinic:
    • 5 Subtypes - M1, M2, M3, M4, M5
    • M1, M3, M5 are Gq coupled receptors
    • M2, M4 are Gi/Go coupled receptors
  • Nicotinic:
    • 2 Subtypes - Nm (Neuromuscular junction), Nn (CNS, Ganglion, Adrenal glands)
    • Nicotinic receptors are ion channels

 

Receptors of Parasympathetic system Subtype Site
Nicotinic Nm Neuromuscular junction
Nn CNS, ganglia, Adrenal gland
Muscarinic M1 CNS, Ganglia, Salivary, and gastric glands
M2 Heart
M3 Smooth muscles, secretory glands, eyes - pupils, and blood vessels
M4 CNS
M5 CNS

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in myasthenia gravis does not alter the disease process?
questions.solution:
Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase agent that does not alter the disease process of myasthenia gravis.

Anticholinesterase agents improve muscle contractions by allowing released acetylcholine to accumulate and act on the receptors over a large area and also have the additional direct depolarizing effect on the motor endplate.

But the underlying disease process continues and ultimately it may not be possible to restore muscle strength with anticholinesterase agents alone. It is due to the reduction of the receptors by the antibodies. It does not alter the disease process but provides symptomatic relief.

Drugs like prednisone, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine are immunosuppressive agents that reduce the antibody titers and can modify the disease process (Options B, C, and D).

questions.text: An asthmatic patient has been taking a salbutamol inhaler to control his wheezing episodes. Which of the following is not an effect seen on stimulation of the receptor involved?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol is a short-acting, selective β2-adrenergic receptor agonist used in the treatment of asthma and COPD.  β2 receptors mediate the stimulation of lipolysis (not inhibition). 

Adrenergic control of adipose tissue:

  • Stimulation of lipolysis - α1, β1, β2, and β3 receptors
  • Inhibition of lipolysis - α2
Adrenergic receptor Actions
α1 receptor
  • Vasoconstriction of large arterioles
  • Genito-urinary smooth muscle - contraction
  • Uterine muscles contraction
  • Mydriasis - by contraction of radial muscles of the iris
  • Increase secretion of glands
  • Gastrointestinal relaxation
α2 receptor
  • Autoregulatory in the sympathetic system
  • Vasoconstriction of precapillary arterioles in skeletal muscles
  • Decrease insulin synthesis
β1 receptor
  • Increased rhythmicity and force of contraction of the heart
  • Increased renin secretion - JG cells in the kidney
β2 receptor
  • Smooth muscle relaxation: vasodilation, bronchodilation
  • Uterine muscle relaxation
  • Stimulation of lipolysis
  • Increased insulin secretion
  • Increased hepatic gluconeogenesis
  • Increased muscle glycogenolysis
β3 receptor
  • Stimulation of lipolysis
  • Relaxation of detrusor

questions.text: A patient who was started on treatment for glaucoma comes to the casualty with acute onset breathlessness. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze is heard. Which of the following drugs might have led to this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchial asthma which was most likely precipitated by timolol.

Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation. It precipitates bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals by beta-2 blockade.

Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF-2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma. 

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about aspirin?

choices.text: It is an irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase enzyme.
Its clearance is independent of plasma concentration at low dose.
Alkalinization of urine increases its rate of excretion.
Its antiplatelet effect at low dose is related to presystemic COX inhibition.

questions.solution:
Aspirin clearance is dependent on plasma concentration at a lower dose.

Aspirin shows saturation kinetics. This means that at lower plasma concentrations it has first-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is independent of its plasma concentration.

Around 80-90% of aspirin (salicylates) are bound to plasma proteins, especially albumin.

Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets in the portal circulation (pre-systemic) and deactivates it which is responsible for antiplatelet action.

Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin, as ionised form of aspirin increases which is not reabsorbed from the tubular fluid in kidney. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 12-year-old child developed fever during an epidemic of influenza. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome.

Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome on administration of aspirin or other salicylates.

Features of Reye syndrome include:

  • Acute onset of encephalopathy
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Fatty infiltration of the liver 

Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections.

Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for ketanserin?
questions.solution:
Ketanserin has selective 5-HT2 receptor blocking property with negligible action on 5-HT1, 5-HT3 and 5 HT4-7 receptors and no partial agonistic activity. Among 5-HT2 receptors, blockade of 5-HT2A is stronger than a 5-HT2C blockade.

Ketanserin is an effective antihypertensive, but alpha 1 adrenergic blockade appears to be causative rather than a 5-HT blockade.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented to the ER with an acute attack of migraine. You decide to administer a long-acting triptan. Which among the following do you choose?
questions.solution:
Frovatriptan is a long-acting triptan among other triptans.

Headache recurrences in an attack are less with longer-acting triptans like frovatriptan and naratriptan but onset of action may be slow.

Related Pearl: Triptans - 5HT 1B/1D agonists

Few important properties of triptans:

  • Longest acting triptan: Frovatriptan
  • Fastest (Oral) acting triptan: Rizatriptan
  • Least bioavailability (Oral): Sumatriptan

questions.text: A patient having persistent allergic rhinitis is on treatment with intranasal steroids. You wish to add an antihistamine to his treatment regimen. He requests an intranasal preparation. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Azelastine is an antihistamine which has an intranasal preparation for allergic rhinitis.

Olopatadine and azelastine are the second generations antihistaminics available as intranasal (nasal spray) preparations for allergic rhinitis. They have good topical activity.

Intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) remain the preferred monotherapy for persistent allergic rhinitis (AR). However, additional studies support the additive benefit of combination treatment with INCS and intranasal antihistamines in AR. For patients receiving INCS, an intranasal decongestant may be added to the treatment for upto 4 weeks.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male was rushed to the ER with complaints of chest pain for the past 45 minutes and was started on isosorbide mononitrate. How does this drug act?
questions.solution:
Nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate act by increasing the concentration of the second messenger cGMP.

They are used to relieve angina and cause vasodilation.

questions.text: All of the following are drugs used for the treatment of congestive heart failure except _________.
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase inhibitor used for angina pectoris.

Options A, B, and C:

Note: Trimetazidine use has a significant association with the development of Parkinson's disease and hence, it is not a first line anti-anginal agent.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with hypertension during routine health evaluation. Which of the following is not recommended as first-line therapy for him?
questions.solution:
Alpha blockers like doxazosin are not recommended as first-line therapy for uncomplicated essential hypertension.

As per the European Society of Cardiology 2018 guidelines for hypertension, the classes of drugs recommended as first line therapy are:

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of both feet and of breathlessness on exertion. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with cardiac failure.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channel blockade?
  1. Procainamide
  2. Phenytoin
  3. Flecainide
  4. Mexiletine
  5. Propafenone
questions.solution:
Phenytoin and mexiletine which are class IB antiarrhythmic drugs have the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channel blockade.

They show the fastest dissociation kinetics to Na+ channel blockade (<1 sec).

 

Na+ channel blockade

Prolonged

K+ channel opener

Shortened or no effect

questions.text: A patient with hypercholesterolemia on statin therapy presents to your OPD for follow-up. You notice his cholesterol is still high and decide to add on another drug that directly inhibits the absorption of cholesterol. Which of the following will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Ezetimibe is the drug that prevents hypercholesterolemia by directly inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol.

Ezetimibe acts by interfering with a specific cholesterol transport protein NPC1L1 in the intestinal mucosa and reduces the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. It causes a compensatory increase in hepatic cholesterol synthesis but LDL cholesterol is decreased. Statins block this enhanced cholesterol synthesis (cholesterol synthesis inhibitors) and so their combination has a synergistic effect.

Option B: Orlistat is an anti-obesity drug that acts by inhibiting pancreatic and gastric lipase and thus interferes with the digestion and absorption of dietary triglycerides.

Option C: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant. The bile-acid sequestrants are highly positively charged and bind negatively charged bile acids. Because of their large size, the resins are not absorbed, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool.

Cholestyramine primarily reduces LDL levels by increasing hepatic bile acid synthesis; which results in increased LDL uptake and diversion of cholesterol to bile acid production. 

Option D: Niacin reduces lipolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and reduces hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases both plasma renin activity and plasma renin concentration ?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers decrease both plasma renin activity and plasma renin concentration by decreasing sympathetic flow. 

 

Plasma renin activity 

 Plasma renin concentration 
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  Increase Increase
Angiotensin receptor blockers Increase Increase
Direct renin inhibitors Decrease  Increase
Beta-blockers  Decrease Decrease
Diuretics  Increase Increase

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis presenting with ascites and pedal edema is administered conivaptan. Which of the following statements regarding the drug is true?
questions.solution:
Conivaptan is a nonselective vasopressin receptor antagonist.

Conivaptan antagonizes both V1a and V2 receptors. It is administered intravenously and is used in the treatment of euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. Vaptans have been proven to mobilize ascites and improve hyponatremia in patients with cirrhosis.

Vasopressin receptor blockers are classified as:

V1b selective(V3 RA) Nelivaptan
V2 selective(V2 RA) Lixivaptan
Mozavaptan

Tolvaptan

questions.text: Which of the following is false about penicillins?

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin is short acting penicillin
Cloxacillin is beta lactamase and acid resistant
Ampicillin is not resistant to beta lactamases

questions.solution:
Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting.

They are given as deep I.M. injection. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks.

Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally.

Ampicillin has an extended spectrum but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.

Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:

  • Cloxacillin
  • Dicloxacillin
  • Flucloxacillin
  • Methicillin
  • Nafcillin

Cefixime is a third-generation oral cephalosporin.

questions.text: The following factors increase theophylline clearance except:
questions.solution:
High carbohydrate intake decreases the clearance of theophylline. 

Factors increasing clearance of theophylline:

  • Enzyme induction (CYP1A2) by coadministered drugs 
  • Smoking tobacco/marijuane by CYP1A2 induction 
  • High-protein, low carbhohydrate diet 
  • Barbecued meat 
  • Childhood 

Factors decreasing clearance of theophylline, thus causing toxicity:

  • Enzyme inhibition (CYP1A2) by coadministered drugs such as ciprofloxacin
  • Congestive heart failure 
  • Liver disease 
  • Pneumonia 
  • Viral infection and vaccination 
  • High-carbhohydrate diet

questions.text: A middle-aged man tried to abscond so that he could avoid service of summons. Which section of the BNS/IPC respectively deals with this scenario?
questions.solution:
Section 206 of BNS (172 of IPC) deals with absconding to avoid service of summons or other proceedings.

Common IPC Sections dealing with summons include:

questions.text: Suspended animation can occur in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Suspended animation is not seen in throttling (manual strangulation).

Suspended animation is a condition where signs of life are absent as functions are interrupted for some time or are reduced to a minimum.

It is seen in the following conditions:

  1. Vagal inhibition
  2. Severe syncopal attacks
  3. Narcotic poisoning
  4. Shock
  5. Cerebral concussion
  6. Insanity
  7. Newborn infants
  8. Drowning
  9. Hypothermia
  10. Electrocution
  11. Sunstroke
  12. Cholera
  13. After anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal term corpus delicti?
questions.solution:
Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offense, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.

The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of the identity of the dead body and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place, by the person or persons charged with a crime and none other. 

A conviction for an offense does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborative evidence.

In a charge of homicide, it includes:

  • Positive identification of the dead body (victim)
  • Proof of its death by a criminal act of the accused

questions.text: An elderly man was brought to the OPD with cold hands and feet. He was found unconscious in a snowstorm near his village. On examination, his temperature showed 32.5°C. Which among the following is least likely to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
Extradural hematoma is not a common finding in patients with hypothermia. 

Autopsy findings of hypothermia:

  • Pink discoloration of the skin - due to persistent oxyhemoglobin in the skin capillaries.
  • Acute gastric erosions - The stomach mucosa is frequently studded with numerous shallow ulcers called Wischnewski spots. The floor of each spot contains a dark brown plug of altered blood.
  • Acute pancreatitis - present in less than half the deaths from proven hypothermia.
  • Pulmonary edema.
  • Perivascular hemorrhages.

The image below shows Wischnewski spots:

Note: A condition resembling extradural hematoma may be found in burns patients, called heat hematoma.

questions.text: In an abrasion caused by tangential force, which of the following indicates the direction of said force?
questions.solution:
In an abrasion caused by a tangential force, the direction of the force is determined by epidermal tags. 

Abrasions caused by a tangential force are known as 'brush abrasion' or 'grazes' or 'brush burn.' It is commonly seen when a body is dragged over a rough surface, such as a road. This scrapes linear furrows across the skin. The epidermal tags raised by the impact tend to pile up at the distal end.

The method of formation of epidermal tags is given in the image below.

Option A: Fishtailing is the shape of the stab wound caused by a single-edged weapon.

Option C: Tailing of the wound indicates the direction of injury in incised wounds. 

Option D: Crushed hair follicles are seen at the edge of the wound in a laceration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old fisherman was brought dead. His autopsy findings revealed emphysema aquosum. What is the most probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Emphysema aquosum is seen in cases of wet drowning.

Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning.

The oedema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But, the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aquosum - overinflation of the lungs
  • Paltauf’s spots - subpleural haemorrhages that reflect haemolysis within intra-alveolar haemorrhages
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - subjective and non-specific finding
  • Foreign material in the stomach - watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed or sand
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - a positive non-specific sign of drowning
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses - not a reliable diagnostic sign of drowning

Note: The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. The most useful one is froth in the air passages.

questions.text: A man is heartbroken because his girlfriend recently left him to marry another man. He decides to get drunk that night, to cope with his feelings. On waking up the next morning, he finds that he has set fire to her car. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the man?

choices.text: He is guilty under Sec 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS)
He is guilty under Sec 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS)
He can be charged under Sec 510 IPC (Sec 355 BNS)
He can be charged under Sec 86 IPC (24 BNS)

questions.solution:
This man can be charged under Sec 86 IPC (Sec 24 BNS).

According to this section, an act is considered a crime only if done with certain knowledge or intent, a person who commits the act while intoxicated will be assumed to have had that knowledge as if they were not intoxicated. This assumption does not apply if the person was intoxicated without their knowledge or against their will.

Option A: Section 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS) - Act of a person of unsound mind—No act is an offence which is undertaken by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or understanding of what is being done is either wrong or contrary to law. This does not apply to the man, who was not of unsound mind. Section 84 IPC (Sec 22 BNS) does apply in the case of delirium tremens.

Section 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS)- No act is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it, by reason of intoxication, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to law; provided that what intoxicated him was administered to him without his knowledge or against his will. Here, Section 85 IPC (Sec 23 BNS) does not apply because the alcohol was not administered to him against his will.

Option C: Section 510 IPC (Sec 355 BNS) - Misconduct by a drunken person in public is punishable with imprisonment of up to 24 hours. This does not apply here as the man was not caught committing the crime while in a state of intoxication.

questions.text: A woman was slowly poisoning her husband by adding arsenic to his food daily. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia (pink disease) is a feature of mercury poisoning, not arsenic poisoning.

Features of chronic arsenic exposure:

  • Skin lesions-
    • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pigmentation resembling measles) or hypopigmentation
    • Hyperkeratosis of palms and soles.
    • Nail changes (Mees lines)
    • Skin carcinomas and Bowen disease
    • Peripheral vascular disease leading to Blackfoot disease (gangrene)
  • Neurologic manifestations -
    • Polyneuropathy
    • Painful paraesthesia of hands and feet
  • Cardiovascular - coronary heart disease and stroke
  • Endocrine - Diabetes Mellitus type 2

Note: Some people take arsenic daily as a tonic or as an aphrodisiac and they acquire tolerance to 250–300 mg or more in one dose. Such people are known as arsenophagists.

The image below shows hyperkeratosis of palms.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a history of having swallowed mercury from a thermometer. History is suggestive of intellectual disability since childhood. What is your next step of action?

choices.text: Gastric lavage and activated charcoal administration

questions.solution:
The mercury found in a glass thermometer is elemental mercury. The absorption of elemental mercury by the GI tract is usually negligible, unless the mucosa is damaged. Hence, no treatment is required.

For ingestion of inorganic and organic mercury salts, the following steps are followed:

  • Aggressive IV hydration
  • GI decontamination, including gastric lavage 
  • Activated charcoal

Dimercaprol and succimer are the preferred chelators for mercury poisoning.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with suspected heavy metal poisoning is as shown below. What is the mechanism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows basophilic stippling, which occurs due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase.

Basophilic stippling in red blood cells occurs due to impaired clearing of cellular RNA degradation products (due to inhibition of pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase).

This finding is seen in the following:

  • Lead toxicity
  • Arsenic toxicity
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Thalassemias

questions.text: Which of the following is false about live vaccines?

choices.text: Simultaneous administration of  two live vaccines should be done in the same syringe
Two live vaccines can be administered simultaneously
Immuno-compromised state poses a contraindication to live vaccines
Live vaccines contain both major and minor antigens

questions.solution:
Simultaneous administration of vaccines is defined as administering more than one vaccine on the same clinic day, at different anatomic sites. They are not combined in the same syringe.

Simultaneous administration of the most widely used live and inactivated vaccines does not result in decreased antibody responses or increased rates of adverse reaction. However, in children with functional or anatomic asplenia pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) and Menactra brand meningococcal conjugate vaccines should not be administered at the same visit; separate these vaccines by at least 4 weeks.

Advantages of simultaneous administration of vaccines:

  • The organisms multiply in the host and thus, the antigenic dose is larger than what is injected.
  • They have all the major and minor antigenic components.

Live vaccines should not be administered to those with an immunocompromised state, since they may cause severe systemic disease by way of viremia/bacteriemia.

Note: If live vaccines are not given simultaneously, they must be spaced as follows-

  • The administration of two live parenteral vaccines or live intranasal influenza vaccines must be separated by at least 4 weeks (28 days).
  • If two live vaccines are given less than 4 weeks apart, the second vaccine should be repeated in four weeks. This is because the live vaccine given first can interfere with the second vaccine, and the person may not develop active immunity to the second vaccine.

Injected and intranasal live vaccines are not believed to have an effect on live oral vaccines. Live oral vaccines may be given at any time before or after administration of live injected or intranasal vaccines.

questions.text: A researcher is planning to study the etiology of certain painful idiopathic peripheral neuropathies. Which of the following study methods shall he choose?
questions.solution:
Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology.

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

questions.text: A case-control study was conducted to evaluate the association between lifestyle risk factors and the prevalence of dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an advantage of this type of study?
questions.solution:
Incidence cannot be calculated from case-control studies. Incidence can be calculated from cohort studies, also known as longitudinal studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Surveillance data of an endemic disease reveals that most of the children in the area had been affected and had to be hospitalised. However, most of the adults remained asymptomatic carriers. Which category does this disease belong to?
questions.solution:
The disease in question belongs to the category of holoendemic diseases. In such diseases, a higher prevalence and pathogenic response are seen among the children in an area. The adults tend to be either asymptomatic carriers or show reduced damage by the disease process. E.g, malaria.

An endemic disease is a disease that is present constantly in a population or in a given area without importation from outside. E.g, kala-azar in Bihar.

A hyperendemic disease is a disease that is constantly present at high incidence and prevalence among all groups in a population. E.g, dengue in India.

A syndemic is the aggregation of two or more concurrent or sequential epidemics or disease clusters in a population with biological interactions, which exacerbate the prognosis and burden of disease. It is also known as a synergistic epidemic.

Note: Quasiendemic is not a term used in infectious disease epidemiology.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic cycle of various countries. In which stages of the cycle will she notice an increase and a decrease in the demographic gap respectively?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing in stage 2 and starts decreasing in stage 3.

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rate and death rate which develops when a country undergoes a demographic transition.

In stage 2 of the demographic cycle, the death rate declines but the birth rate remains unchanged. Hence, the demographic gap increases and reaches a maximum by the end of stage 2. In stage 3, both the death rate and birth rate are declining so the demographic gap starts decreasing.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is the major contributor to demographic burden?
questions.solution:
Demographic burden refers to an increase in the total dependency ratio. It is mostly caused by an increased old-age dependency ratio.

The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility. A decline in dependency ratio especially the young-age dependency ratio has been identified to be a key factor in the underlying rapid economic development.

The potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 per one older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: Which of the following women will not be considered ideal candidates for IUD insertion?

choices.text: A woman in a monogamous relationship
A woman with no access to follow up
A woman who has at least one living child

questions.solution:
A woman with no access to follow-up is not considered an ideal candidate for IUD insertion. 

An ideal candidate for an IUD must have the following attributes:

  • Has at least one child
  • No history of pelvic disease
  • Normal menstrual periods
  • Must be willing to check IUD tail
  • Has access to follow up and for treatment of potential problems
  • Is in a monogamous relationship

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of solid waste or refuse disposal?
questions.solution:
Oxidation ponds are not used for solid waste or refuse disposal. It is used for sewage treatment.

Methods of solid waste disposal are:

  • Dumping
  • Controlled tipping
  • Incineration
  • Composting
  • Manure pits
  • Burial

questions.text: During your posting as a rural medical officer, you conduct an awareness drive prior to the monsoon season in order to highlight the necessity of water purification. Which of the following methods would you not recommend for a household setup?
questions.solution:
Slow sand filter is a method of filtration used for the purification of water on a large scale.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: What is ventilation provided by wind blowing through a space called?
questions.solution:
Ventilation provided by wind blowing through a space is called perflation.

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:

Natural ventilation includes:

  • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
  • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings
  • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation includes:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the housing standards in India?

choices.text: Roof not less than 10 feet from the ground
Daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area
Air space per capita must be 250 – 500 cubic feet

questions.solution:
Air space per capita must be 500 - 1000 cubic feet.

Non-Rural Housing Standards in India:

Housing parameters

Description
Site

Elevated to protect from rains and floods.

Independent access to the street.

Away from vector breeding sites and other pollutants like smoke, noise, dust.

The soil on which it is founded must be dry and safe.
Floor A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks, damp-proof. The height of the plinth must be 2 – 3 feet.
Walls 9 inch thick, strong, low heat capacity, weather-resistant, unsuitable for harbourage of rats/vermin.
Roof Height not less than 10 feet (3m).
Rooms The number of rooms must be according to the size of the family but the basic number is two.
Floor area A living room should have at least 120 sq. ft. of area for occupancy of more than 1 person and 100 sq. ft. for occupancy of only one person. 50 -100 sq. ft. floor area per person is optimum in a living room.
Cubic space 500 – 1000 cubic feet of air space per capita.
Windows At least 2 windows per room with one opening into an open space. Windows must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above the ground. The window area must be 1/5th of the floor area.
Lighting The daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area.
Sanitary privy Every house must have a sanitary privy.
Others Proper facilities for garbage disposal, bathing and washing and a good water supply.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following is true about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

choices.text: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. They have spotted wings.

They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface of water. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially when feeding.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases should healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste be vaccinated against?
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against hepatitis B and tetanus.

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste. Yearly health check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a ceramic factory. What particle size of the dust inhaled would you be most concerned about?
questions.solution: Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called pneumoconioses.

questions.text: Workers working at which of the following industries require periodical examination on a daily basis?
questions.solution:
Workers handling irritant chemicals like dichromates require periodical examination on a daily basis.

Most occupational exposures require an annual periodical examination. Certain exposures like lead, radon, and dyes require monthly periodical examination.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.solution:
Factories act prohibits children of <14 years from being employed.

Children between 15–18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM–7 PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.

The maximum working hours for an adult industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day; if overtime is paid, then it should be not more than 60 hrs per week.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A farmer residing in West Bengal brings his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine immunization. The child has been adequately immunized till now and has already received a measles vaccine during a supplementary immunization activity drive a few months back. What will you administer to him now?

choices.text: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A
OPV booster, DPT booster, JE vaccine and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.solution:
Vaccines to be given at 16 months of age are OPV booster, DPT booster, MR, JE, and Vitamin A.

The child should receive routine doses of the measles vaccine according to the schedule irrespective of the measles supplementary immunisation activity (SIA) dose. So, the second dose of the measles vaccine is also given.

Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is endemic in rural agricultural areas, often associated with rice cultivation and flood irrigation. Vaccination for JE is given in endemic states only. Two doses of a live attenuated JE vaccine are given under the Universal Immunisation Programme (UIP) schedule. Under the Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) schedule, two doses of a new vero cell-derived inactivated JE vaccine are given.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the National Deworming Programme?

choices.text: It is conducted in the months of March and September
Free tablets are given to children up to the age of 15 years
It is carried out in schools and anganwadis
Age appropriate dose of tablet metronidazole is recommended

questions.solution:
The National Deworming programme is carried out in schools and anganwadis.

It is conducted twice a year, in the months of February and August, covering all the children from the age of 1 to 19 years. All the children are given age-appropriate dose of tablet albendazole.

In the states of Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh, it is carried out only once a year (as the prevalence is <20% in these states).

questions.text: You are working as the PHC Medical Officer in your village. Which of the following diseases would you not target under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
The National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) does not target the prevention and control of cutaneous leishmaniasis (also known as Chiclero's ulcer).

NVBDCP is the nodal agency for the prevention and control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Lymphatic filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis 
  • Chikungunya. 

The logo of the NVBDCP:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the surveillance system set up for malaria?

choices.text: Active case detection is carried out when patients report with fever to the peripheral health workers
Blood smears are collected fortnightly during house visits by Accredited Social Health Activists
Antibody detecting rapid diagnostic kits are used for passive case detection as part of surveillance
Passive case detection at the Primary Health Centre is done by examination of blood smears

questions.solution:
Passive case detection at Primary Health Centres (PHCs) is done by examination of blood smears.

Malaria surveillance system:

Active case detection: blood smears are collected by the Multipurpose Health Workers (MPHW)/ Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) on house visits every fortnight.

Passive case detection: detection of fever case by collecting of blood smears of those that report to ASHAs or peripheral health volunteers.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters would you use to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
The Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER) is used to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria. It takes into account the number of slides examined for the population under surveillance.

World Malaria Day is conducted on April 25 every year.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the vestibule?

choices.text: It is a part of the membranous labyrinth
It is part of the auditory pathway

questions.solution:
Vestibule contains the spherical recess for the saccule.

It is part of the bony labyrinth and not part of the auditory pathway. The inside of the medial wall presents with recesses & openings:

  • A spherical recess, which lodges the saccule
  • An elliptical recess, which lodges the utricle
  • An opening for aqueduct of vestibule
  • An opening for the semicircular canals

questions.text: CT scans of a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma reveal that the tumor has undergone a local spread, destroying the anterior wall of the middle ear. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The prominence of the facial canal is least likely to be injured in this given clinical scenario because it is a part of the medial wall of the middle ear and not the anterior wall. 

The anterior wall of the middle ear is related to the following structures:

  • Eustachian tube
  • The canal for tensor tympani
  • Internal carotid artery

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with supraglottic carcinoma. Which of the following lymph node levels is the earliest to be involved?
questions.solution:
Level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most common and earliest nodes involved in supraglottic carcinoma.

questions.text: Otologic examination of a febrile child with otalgia is shown below. What is the stage of acute suppurative otitis media seen here?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and image show the stage of pre-suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). 

During this stage, due to prolonged tubal occlusion, pyogenic organisms invade the tympanic cavity. An inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear and there is congestion of pars tensa.

A leash of blood vessels appears along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the whole of the tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.

Symptoms of this stage include marked earache, a high degree of fever, hearing loss, and tinnitus (seen only in adults). Tuning fork tests show the conductive type of hearing loss.

questions.text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. 

Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:

  • As a sequela of acute otitis media
  • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
  • Allergic conditions

Bone destruction is not present in this type.

Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Ménière’s disease is labyrinthectomy. 

Labyrinthectomy involves uniform destruction of hearing and vestibular function. Ideal candidates have no functional hearing and have failed more conservative treatments, such as gentamicin injection. Despite this morbidity, labyrinthectomy has the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), more than vestibular neurectomy (78-90%), and is considered the single definitive treatment.

The step-by-step management approach for Ménière's disease consists of dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants as the initial measures, followed by intratympanic gentamicin ablation, and finally, surgical intervention.

Primarily, the management of Menier's disease involves a sodium restricted diet and diuretics like acetazolamide (Option A). They are more useful for short-term control. 

Gentamicin (Option D) is a selective vestibulotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic that is preferentially taken up by type I hair cells. It is opted for only if dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants have failed to control the symptoms. If used judiciously, hearing is preserved.

The options for surgical management include - Endolymphatic sac surgery, vestibular neurectomy, and labyrinthectomy. Endolymphatic sac surgery is currently declining in popularity due to lack of evidence of vertigo control. 

Vestibular neurectomy (Option C) refers to selective ablation of the vestibular nerve. Even though it is considered a hearing sparing surgery and carries comparable rates of vertigo control as labyrinthectomy, it is an intradural procedure and carries a greater risk of complications. Hearing loss will still progress as it would have in the natural course of illness.

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding botulism except

choices.text: Infant botulism is caused by ingestion of preformed toxin
Clostridium botulinum toxins A,B,E and F cause human disease
The gene for botulinum toxin is chromosomal mediated

questions.solution:
Infant botulism occurs due to the ingestion of spores, not a preformed toxin. The toxin is released inside the body.

Food-borne botulism occurs due to preformed toxin mixed with canned food.

Other options: 

Option b:  Clostridium botulinum Toxin types A, B, E, and (rarely) F cause disease in humans.  Although type G has not been known to cause any disease in humans, few reports of sudden deaths have been recorded. Type C and D cause disease in animals.
Option c: Botulinum toxins can be chromosomally mediated, plasmid-mediated or phage mediated.
Option d: Rare strains of other clostridia species such as Clostridium butyricum and Clostridium baratii, have been found to cause botulism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
questions.solution:
Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation.

Causes of septal perforation:

  • Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
  • Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays
  • Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis
  • Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma
  • Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis

Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts.

Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and bland ointments.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections presents with diplopia and protrusion of the left eyeball. Inflammation of which of the following paranasal sinuses would most likely lead to this complication?
questions.solution: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of orbital complications secondary to sinusitis. The orbit and its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, but most of the complications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only by a thin lamina of bone called lamina papyracea.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?
questions.solution:
Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space. Trismus is seen in pre-styloid abscess due to the involvement of medial pterygoid muscle.

Parapharyngeal space is divided into two compartments by the styloid process and its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

In a post-styloid abscess, there is a bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, accompanied by paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X (resulting in vocal cord paralysis), XI, XII, and the sympathetic chain, which can manifest as Horner's syndrome. Swelling in the parotid region may also be present. Notably, trismus, the inability to fully open the mouth, is usually absent in this type of abscess.

A pre-styloid abscess exhibits distinct features including the prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa, along with trismus caused by the spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle. Marked odynophagia is common. Additionally, an external swelling can be observed behind the angle of the jaw.

Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemic toxicity are common features.

Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion of thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magnetic resonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful.

Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible.

The image attached below shows the components of both spaces:

questions.text: A woman comes to the ophthalmology OPD because of having vision difficulties for the last 3 months. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a fundus typical of pathological myopia due to the stretching of the retina.

The tigroid appearance or tessellated appearance of the fundus can be appreciated. As the eye enlarges, the retinal pigment epithelium becomes thinner, resulting in:

  • A tessellated (checkered) appearance of the fundus
  • Increased visibility of the choroidal vasculature

Other features of the myopic fundus are as follows:

  • Lacquer cracks are spontaneous ruptures of the elastic lamina of Bruch’s membrane. It appears yellowish-white. it is usually located in the posterior pole.
  • Annular gray shadow around the optic disc
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Foster Fuchs spots
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Total retinal atrophy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The condition is commonly associated with a benign course.
It can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension.
The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival haemorrhage in the eye. In this condition, the blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks time without treatment.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. The condition is commonly associated with a benign course but, if the posterior limit of the hemorrhage is not seen, one should check for the base of the skull fracture. 

Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukaemia. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.text: Your aunt recently shared that it is becoming cumbersome for her to frequently change her glasses. You suggested a referral and the rapid change in power was diagnosed to be due to keratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done on her. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution:
The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography, and it is used for conditions like keratoconus, as seen in this clinical scenario.

Corneal topography captures the shape of the cornea by projecting concentric rings of light onto its anterior surface, forming a Placido disc pattern. the reflected light is analyzed with specialised software to create a detailed map of the corneal curvature. 

Uses:

  • Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus
  • To measure corneal thickness
  • Prior to refractive surgery
  • Sometimes prior to contact lens fitting

The image shows a Placido or Keratoscopic disc which is used for corneal surface assessment. 

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: A 69-year-old man who is a chronic smoker, hypertensive, and has a BMI of 35 kg/m2 complains of diminished vision in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36 BE and the anterior segment appears normal. His fundus is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image which shows drusen (druplets) are a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (ARMD). 

Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of ARMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

There are two types of ARMD:

  • Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) ARMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Initially characterized by macular Drusens, which later progress to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry ARMD. Antioxidants like the AREDS2 supplements have proven effective.
  • Wet (exudative, neovascular) ARMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

questions.text: A young patient presents with loss of central vision. There is a family history of a similar condition. Both EOG and ERG are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario is Stargardt's disease.

Stargardt's disease also known as Stargardt macular dystrophy or fundus flavimaculatus is the most common macular dystrophy. It most commonly is inherited in an autosomal-recessive manner caused by a mutation on an adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette (ABCA4) gene.

Characterized by macular "pisciform" flecks that accumulate at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), sometimes resulting in central macular atrophy early in life. Patients develop a macula with a “beaten bronze” appearance caused by atrophic changes in the RPE. In addition, a "dark" or "silent" choroid is seen on the fluorescein angiography that appears as a prominent retinal circulation against hypofluorescent choroid. 

The electroretinogram (ERG) and electro-oculography (EOG) are normal early in the disease but may be reduced in more advanced cases. Of note, the ERG findings do not directly correlate with clinical findings.

There is no known proven treatment for this disease. Because ABCA4 plays a role in vitamin A processing in the visual cycle, additional vitamin A is suspected to make the disease worse.

The image below shows macular pisciform flecks.

Other options: 

Option A: Retinitis pigmentosa: abnormal electroretinogram (ERG).

Option B: Rod–cone dystrophy: abnormal ERG.

Option D: Best's disease: Normal ERG with abnormal electrooculogram (EOG).

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with progressive deterioration of vision. The pupillary reaction is sluggish and the IOP is elevated. Fundoscopy shows a large and deep cup and the visual field reveals paracentral scotoma. What is the first line of treatment for this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of deterioration of vision, sluggish pupils, elevated IOP and paracentral scotoma is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Timolol is one of the first-line agents used in the treatment of primary open-angle glaucoma.

First-line agents for the treatment of glaucoma are:

  • Prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost and bimatoprost
  • Topical beta-blockers such as timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol 
  • Selective alpha 2 adrenergic agonist brimonidine

Adjunctive therapy: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Laser trabeculoplasty: In cases where intraocular pressure (IOP) is uncontrolled despite maximal tolerated medical therapy.

Note: Since prostaglandin (PG) analogs are not included in the options, the next best option to choose is timolol.

Historically, beta-blockers were the most common first-line agents used in the medical treatment of POAG. However, with an increase in our experience with newer agents, specifically the prostaglandin analogues that facilitate outflow, they were recognized as being more efficacious in lowering IOP and systemically safer than beta-blockers. As a result, now they are the first-line agents in glaucoma treatment.

questions.text: An elderly male who is a known case of diabetes presents with blurry vision near the center of his field of vision. He also informs that colours appear washed out or faded. His IOP was found to be elevated. Which of the following drugs should not be used to control IOP in this diabetic patient?
questions.solution:
This diabetic patient with new onset central loss of vision and reports of colors appearing faded or washed out most likely has macular edema. Prostaglandin analogs have a high propensity to cause and further exacerbate cystoid macular edema and hence are not preferred in this patient. 

Drugs associated with cystoid macular edema (CME):

  1. Prostaglandin analogues
  2. Epinephrine
  3. Dipivefrine (only the non-selective alpha agonists, in aphakic eyes)
  4. Tamoxifen
  5. Timolol
  6. Docetaxel
  7. Interferons
  8. Fingolimod
  9. Thiazolinediones
  10. Niacin (pseudo-CME)

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has bilateral optic atrophy with diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wolfram syndrome. It is due to WFS1 gene mutation. 

The presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years; diabetes mellitus is typically the first manifestation, followed by visual problems. It has a poor prognosis. 

Clinical features are: (DIDMOAD) 

  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Optic atrophy
  • Deafness (sensorineural type) 

Option A: Kjer's optic neuropathy is an autosomal dominant condition. It presents with vision loss in early childhood and no significant systemic features.

Option B: Behr syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Clinical features include optic atrophy, pyramidal tract signs, ataxia, intellectual disability, urinary incontinence, and pes cavus

Option D: Leber's congenital amaurosis is an autosomal recessive condition. It usually presents with significant vision loss in infancy and nystagmus.

questions.text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a left oculomotor nerve palsy.

It is evident by the upper lid ptosis and down and out deviation of the left eye, as seen in the primary position of gaze (central image).

questions.text: Which of the following histological features will you not see in a patient with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)?

choices.text: Distension and distortion of the terminal duct lobular units
Papillary growth pattern within the duct lumina

questions.solution:
The papillary growth pattern within the duct lumina is a feature of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). 

Histological features of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS):

  • LCIS originates from the terminal duct lobular units and is characterized by the distention and distortion of the terminal duct lobular units.
  • Cytoplasmic mucoid globules (signet-ring cells) are a distinctive cellular feature.
  • Neighborhood calcification is a feature that is unique to LCIS and contributes to its diagnosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented to the clinic with a 7 x 3 cm lump in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. On palpation, the lump was found to be fixed to the pectoralis major muscle. What is the T staging of the tumor in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, as the lump is 7 cm in size, the T stage of the tumor is T3 ( >5 cm).

Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4.

However, there are two exceptions:

  • Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4
  • Involvement of the dermis alone does not qualify as T4

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck. He also complained of persistent cough and regurgitation of food remnants shortly after consumption. He underwent a barium swallow which is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Occurs in the midline posteriorly and as sac enlarges lies on the left side
Dohlman’s procedure is indicated when size > 2-5 cm
Herniates through the thyropharyngeus and cricothyroid muscle

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of a Zenker’s diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch. It is caused due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the space between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus. This space is known as Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor in the posterior pharyngeal wall.

It is a pulsion diverticulum, formed due to increased intraluminal pressure forcing mucosa and submucosa to herniate.

A small Zenker’s diverticulum < 2cm is managed by diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy. 

Large diverticulum > 2-5cm is treated by endoscopic diverticulopexy (Dohlman’s procedure) or by a diverticulectomy with cricopharyngeal myotomy. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure
