questions.text: Which of the following factors will increase the risk of a patient developing gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for gastric carcinoma. 

Aspirin, which is a COX inhibitor, is protective against gastric cancer. 

Eating refrigerated food has reduced the need for salting of food for preservation, and thus reduced the incidence of gastric cancer.

Males are more commonly affected as compared to females.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

questions.text: A woman underwent a total gastrectomy 5 months ago for gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the most common metabolic complication expected in her?
questions.solution:
The most common metabolic complication seen after gastrectomy is iron deficiency anemia.

Although absorption of iron occurs primarily in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, it needs an optimum acidic environment for absorption. Hence, due to a combination of decreased iron intake, impaired iron absorption, and chronic blood loss, there is iron deficiency anemia. The addition of iron supplements to the patient’s diet corrects iron deficiency anemia.

Complications of gastrectomy:

  • Dumping syndrome: early and late
  • Nutritional deficiencies- Iron deficiency anemia (most common), Vit B12 deficiency, and osteoporosis
  • Diarrhea
  • Duodenal stump leak/blow out
  • Bile reflux gastritis and esophagitis
  • Gall stones
  • Roux syndrome

questions.text: In Laugier’s hernia, the opening is in the _____
questions.solution:
Laugier’s hernia is an atypical femoral hernia where the sac herniates through a gap in the lacunar (Gimbernat’s) ligament.

Related Pearl: Variants of femoral hernia

Laugier’s femoral hernia:

  • Through a gap in lacunar (Gimbernat) ligament.
  • Always strangulated

Narath’s femoral hernia:

  • Seen in patients with congenital dislocation of hip
  • It is behind the femoral vessels

Cloquet’s hernia:

  • Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

Hesselbach’s hernia:

  • Lateral to femoral artery

Serafini's hernia:

  • Behind the femoral vessels

Velpeau(Prevascular/Teale's) hernia:

  • Infront of femoral vessels

Beclard’s hernia:

  • Through saphenous opening

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of intermittent constipation and a sense of heaviness in his lower abdomen. His barium enema film is given below. Which of the following statements is false about the pathology responsible for his condition?

choices.text: Commonly occurs along the mesenteric side of the colon
Sigmoid colon is the most common site
It is characterized by true diverticula

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray film showing saw-toothed appearance of the colon are suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. They are false diverticula.

Diverticulosis refers to the herniation of the mucosa and muscularis mucosa through the colonic wall, usually at the point where the nutrient artery enters the colon (mesenteric side). The condition is usually asymptomatic until complications arise. They may be detected incidentally. On a barium X-ray, the colon with diverticular disease will have a saw-toothed appearance.

Colonic diverticula are more often acquired than congenital. They are common in developed countries that have a low fiber diet. A low fiber diet results in low stool volume. As the colon generates higher intraluminal pressure to propel smaller volumes of stools, low stool volumes cause an increase in colonic wall tension and segmentation of the colon. 

Prolonged colonic contractions and high pressures (directed radially along the colonic wall) results in the formation of pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common site.

Note: True diverticulum involves the herniation of all the layers of the intestine whereas false diverticulum involves the herniation of only the mucosa and submucosa.

questions.text: An elderly man with per-rectal bleeding is suspected to have rectal carcinoma. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Majority of the cancers are sporadic
Dose of radiation used for this tumor is 45 Gy
Dissection lateral to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence
Precise location of the tumor is determined with rigid proctosigmoidoscopy

questions.solution:
Dissection medial (not lateral) to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence.

Dissection lateral to the avascular anatomic space, risks injury to the mixed autonomic nerves, causing impotence in men and bladder dysfunction in men and women.

Transmesorectal resection involves complete removal of the lymph node bearing mesorectum along with its intact enveloping fascia. It is a curative resection of rectal tumours of the middle and lower thirds of the rectum, either as part of Low Anterior Resection (LAR) or Abdominoperineal Resection (APR).

Option A: The majority of colorectal cancers are sporadic. Approximately 5% of all colorectal cancers are attributed to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer). 

Option B: The large bowel can tolerate delivered radiation doses of up to 6000 cGy. However, a lower dose of 45 Gy is recommended for colorectal tumours. High levels of radiation targeted at colon tumours would include the small bowel in the treatment field. This results in complications such as radiation enteritis. 

Option D: The precise location of the rectal tumour is determined using rigid proctosigmoidoscope or flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy. The other investigations used in rectal cancer include:

  • Digital rectal examination - for assessing the depth of penetration
  • Endorectal ultrasound or MRI - provides an accurate assessment of the extent of invasion of the bowel wall
  • MRI with an endorectal coil - is the investigation of choice to assess the 'T' and 'N' stages
  • CECT - for evaluation of metastasis.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lead poisoning in children is seen due to lead paint and according to the history, it is evident that the case is of lead poisoning and the enzyme defect seen is ALA dehydratase.

Lead is toxic because it can substitute for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. Lead can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood–brain barrier and enter the neuroglia cells which support brain function.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl–CoA and glycine in a reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial ALA Synthase.

Condensation of two molecules of ALA, catalyzed by cytosolic ALA dehydratase forms porphobilinogen which is essential in heme synthesis.

Fatal dose: 20g of lead acetate

Fatal period: 1 to 2 days.

Symptoms:

Abdominal pain, headache, anemia, irritability and, in severe cases, seizures, coma and death.

Diagnosis

X-rays will expose dense lines in the long bones of children and red cells undergo a change known as basophilic stippling, where blue-staining remnants of destroyed DNA are seen lining the margins of the red cells.

The main tool for diagnosis is measurement of the blood lead level.

Treatment depends on the blood level and is designed to remove the lead from the body by chelation therapy.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anal fistula?
questions.solution:
The most common anal fistula is the intersphincteric fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge- intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

 Type of Fistula

Dentate line

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Penetrates the inter-sphincteric space, continues above puborectalis, and penetrates levator ani

Perineal skin or perineum

Extra- sphincteric

Crohn’s disease

questions.text: A patient on total parenteral nutrition may develop a deficiency of _______
questions.solution:
A patient on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may develop a deficiency of zinc, among others.

The commencement of TPN may precipitate or accentuate underlying nutrient deficiency by encouraging anabolism.

Complications of TPN:

  • Infections
    • Highest risk - femoral vein
    • Lowest risk - subclavian vein
  • Metabolic complications
    • CO2 retention and respiratory insufficiency due to excess calorie infusion
    • Hepatic steatosis and marked glycogen deposition
    • Cholestasis and gallstones
  • Intestinal atrophy
    • Mucosal atrophy
    • Bacterial overgrowth
    • Impaired gut immunity

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency with a clean lacerated wound on his forearm. You use the given suturing technique to close his wound. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This technique has the least cut through rate
The wound edges should be everted
Interrupted sutures are used to approximate the wound
After the first bite, the needle should emerge at the of center the wound

questions.solution:
The given image shows interrupted sutures. Horizontal mattress sutures, not interrupted sutures, have the least cut-through rate.

In mattress suture, the initial suture is inserted as an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture.

Continuous suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Subcuticular sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient in the burns unit, who had sustained third-degree burns to her abdomen and lower limbs (BSA of 30%). She had received 9 liters of Ringer's lactate at a primary center. On examination, extensive abdominal eschars are seen. BP - 84/50 mmHg, HR - 118 bpm and urine output has been less than 15 ml for the past 2 hours. The ventilator shows a peak airway pressure of 42 cm H2O. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). Measurement of bladder pressure using a urinary bladder catheter is the next best step in the management of this patient.

The oliguria and hypotension in isolation could be suggestive of under-resuscitation. However, the history of large volume fluid administration, presence of abdominal eschars along with very high peak airway pressures should raise the suspicion for ACS.

Abdominal compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of intra-abdominal pressure > 20mmHg with associated organ compression and dysfunction:

  • Compression of the IVC leads to decreased cardiac output, and consequent increase in systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension. 
  • Cephalad displacement of the diaphragm results in decreased thoracic volumes and results in elevated peak and plateau pressures. 
  • Renal compression can lead to increased renal vascular resistance, decreased GFR and low urine output.  

Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome.

Grade of Intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) Intra-abdominal pressure (IAP)
Grade I 12–15 mmHg
Grade II 16–20 mmHg
Grade III 21–25 mmHg
Grade IV >25 mmHg

Note: Direct methods such as pressure transducers and intraperitoneal catheters are more accurate but are limited by their invasiveness.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: All of the following can be done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except?

choices.text: Strap their thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Place in prone position to prevent aspiration
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient onto a hard board

questions.solution:
Patients with polytrauma are shifted into a supine or prone position (not in a lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface to restrict spinal movement.

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients until proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

The patients are placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (philadelphia collar) is applied. Aspiration can be prevented by putting the patient in the prone position and strapping can be done to provide further stabilization.

Long spine boards with straps are helpful in the rapid transport of the patient from one place to another. The patient can be put on the long spine board by log-rolling (a technique where four people hold the patient and roll the patient like a log without allowing rotation or bending of the spine).

Conscious and alert patient indirectly means that they don’t need intubation and their airway is patent. If the patient is unconscious always check the airway and if needed, endotracheal intubation must be done immediately by various methods. Preferably by direct laryngoscopy and intubation.

questions.text:
While starting fluid resuscitation on a patient with burns, it is important to keep in mind that all of the following parameters will be decreased, except:
  1. Hemoglobin 
  2. Intravascular volume 
  3. Capillary permeability 
  4. Cardiac output
  5. Afterload
questions.solution:
Capillary permeability and afterload is increased after severe burns.

Significant burns is associated with massive release of inflammatory mediators, both in the wound and in other tissues. These mediators produce vasoconstriction and vasodilation, increased capillary permeability, and edema locally and in distant organs.

Cellular and humoral immunity are decreased in burns (increased risk of infection).

Changes in various systems in burns:

CVS

  • Massive edema
  • Increased afterload
  • Decreased venous return
  • Decreased cardiac output

Renal

  • Low volume concentrated urine
  • Decreased urinary sodium
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Renal ischemia
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Acute renal failure

GI

  • Reflex Ileus
  • GI Ulcers (Curling’s Ulcer)

Endocrine and Metabolism

  • Increased glucagon, cortisol
  • Protein catabolism
  • Ureagenesis
  • Lipolysis
  • Increased gluconeogenesis
  • Lactic acidosis

Hematological

  • Anaemia
  • Initial thrombocytopenia then thrombocytosis
  • Decreased capacity of neutrophil phagocytosis
  • Overall lymphopenia
  • Relative increase in T-Suppressor Cells

questions.text: Most common initial presentation of the following thyroid malignancy?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts a follicular thyroid carcinoma. Follicular cancers usually present as solitary thyroid nodules.

Patients with follicular cancers rarely present with cervical lymphadenopathy, thyrotoxicosis or dysphonia. 

Papillary thyroid carcinomas commonly present with cervical lymphadenopathy due to lymph node metastases. They may also present with dysphonia, due to the local invasion.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He had a laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to 10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma on the left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses.

The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands.

Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Identify the given incision used for maxillectomy.
questions.solution:
The image shows Weber–Ferguson incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma.

The rest of the options are incisions used for modified radical neck dissection (MRND).

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Branchial cyst develops due to the persistence of the cervical sinus. The cervical sinus is formed when the 2nd arch mesoderm overgrows the succeeding arches and overhangs them as shown in the image. The space between the overhanging 2nd pharyngeal arch and the 3rd, 4th, and 6th arches is called the cervical sinus. The cavity of the cervical sinus is lined by ectoderm and normally gets obliterated.

Branchial cysts are usually lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid (option B). An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. 

It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.

Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is Escherichia coli.

It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible.

The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis.

Urine examination and culture should be done. Urine examination reveals threads in urine.

Management:  

Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and monitoring of laboratory parameters.

Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. Antibiotics are given for 2-6 weeks to ensure the eradication of the infection as antibiotics don't penetrate the prostate capsule easily. 

For outpatient therapy: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg oral every 12 hours or levofloxacin 500 mg OD or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole double-strength tablet oral every 12 hours can be used.

For hospitalized patients: Intravenous ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin with or without an aminoglycoside (gentamicin or tobramycin) or intravenous beta-lactam with or without an aminoglycoside. Gram-positive infections are treated with cephalosporins (cephalexin, cefazolin) or dicloxacillin and vancomycin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding bladder stone is false?

choices.text: Primary bladder stone develops in sterile urine
Uric acid stones occur  in patients with ileostomies
Triple phosphate calculus  occurs in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.solution:
A cystine calculus occurs only in the presence of cystinuria and is radioopaque because of its high sulfur content.

Primary bladder stone:

  • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.
  • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age
  • Most vesical calculi are mixed
  • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common components of primary bladder calculi

Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.

Types:

  • Calcium oxalate stones
  • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies or with bladder outlet obstruction
  • Cystine stones - in cystinuria
  • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A diabetic primigravida is suspected to have cephalopelvic disproportion. What should her obstetric conjugate be for a trial of labor to be conducted?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, a trial of labor or vaginal delivery can be allowed if the obstetric conjugate is 10cm or more. 

The obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis. Normally, it is 10 cm or more. 

The diagonal conjugate measures 12cm and the true conjugate measures 11cm.

Clinically, only the diagonal conjugate is assessed by measuring the distance between the base of the examiner's fingers and the fingertip touching the sacral promontory.  This determines the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory. The obstetric conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. 

Note: Overt diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia during pregnancy. Thus, it may lead to cephalopelvic disproportion.

Given below is an image of the lateral plane in CT pelvimetry, showing the anteroposterior diameters of the pelvis. Line no. 4 is the obstetric conjugate and line no. 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
There is an increase in the metabolism of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium during normal pregnancy.

The changes in the vagina during pregnancy include:

  • Increased vascularity and hyperemia resulting in a violet/purplish color characteristic of Chadwick's sign
  • Vaginal epithelium undergoes marked proliferation (option D) with the extension of the squamocolumnar junction downwards
  • Vaginal pH decreases and becomes more acidic (option C) and varies from 3.5-6.0.
  • Increase in the number of Lactobacillus acidophilus (option A). It metabolizes the glycogen stores and causes an increased production of lactic acid. Therefore, the pH becomes acidic.
  • Increased volume of cervical secretion during pregnancy results in the production of thick white vaginal discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following is increased during pregnancy?

choices.text: Total oxygen carrying capacity of blood

questions.solution:
The total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood increases during pregnancy.

During pregnancy, there is an increase in total haemoglobin (Hb) resulting in increased total oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. However, there is a relative decrease in Hb concentration (hematocrit) due to a greater increase in plasma volume. This decreases oxygen-carrying capacity per unit volume of blood.

Maternal iron stores are not sufficient to meet the increased demand during pregnancy and hence the serum iron and ferritin concentration falls.

The plasma volume expansion also lowers serum potassium.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has her first antenatal visit in the 8th month of gestation. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 30 weeks and the fetal heart rate is 136/min. What is the best parameter for the estimation of fetal age by USG in this patient?

questions.text: A 34-year-old G3P2L2 woman presents to the ER with hypotension and severe abdominal pain. On examination, fetal parts are palpable over the abdomen. USG abdomen revealed a large uterine wall defect. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of uterine rupture. Maternal tachycardia is seen in this condition.

Clinical features of uterine rupture:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia/absent fetal heart sounds
  • Hypotension
  • Abdominal tenderness
  • Palpable fetal parts on per abdomen examination
  • Bandl’s ring
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria 

Common causes of uterine rupture are previous caesarean delivery, myomectomy, silent rupture (in previous pregnancy), excess use of oxytocin, grand multipara, uterine overdistension, obstructed labour, difficult forceps delivery, placenta percreta

questions.text: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.

In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions. This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign. 

Sonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Single placental mass
  • Presence of intervening membrane - T sign
  • Thin intervening membrane <2mm

The best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34 - 37weeks + 6 days.

Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda sign

Image 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between them

Image 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.text: Antigens of which of the following blood group systems do not cause alloimmunization in a newborn/fetus?
questions.solution:
The Lewis antigens do not cause alloimmunization or hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn.

Alloimmunization/isoimmunisation is defined as an immune response to foreign antigens after exposure to genetically different cells or tissues.

The Kell blood group system is complex and contains many antigens that are highly immunogenic. These antigens are the third most potent, after those of the ABO and Rh blood groups, at triggering an immune reaction. Anti-Kell causes severe fetal anemia by suppressing fetal RBC synthesis. 

MNS and Kidd blood types cause alloimmunization. Hemolytic disease of newborn is mild with Kidd whereas MNS causes potentially severe anemia.

questions.text: Identify this condition.
questions.solution:
The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as:

  • 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic)
  • No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetuses must have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic). 

Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placenta and intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetus will have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This is seen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days.

The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cords arising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps.

Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it’s own amnion & chorion. The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well as monozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days.

Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)  most commonly complicates monochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twin to the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving the donor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic.

questions.text:
Match the following criteria used for the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
1) Abdominal A) Spiegelberg
2) Cervical B) Studdiford
3) Cornual C) Rubin
4) Ovarian
questions.solution:
Ectopic pregnancy Criteria
Abdominal Studdiford
Cervical Rubin
Ovarian  Spiegelberg

Spiegelberg’s criteria used for the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy include intact ipsilateral tube, pregnancy occupying ovary connected by the utero-ovarian ligament.

Studdiford’s criteria used for the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy include the presence of normal bilateral tubes and pregnancy related to the peritoneal surface.

Rubin's criteria used for the diagnosis of cervical pregnancy includes presence of soft, enlarged cervix and closed internal os and partially opened external os.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

choices.text: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.solution:
In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor of pre-eclampsia.

In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of preeclampsia.

 Predictors of preeclampsia:

  • Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma
  • Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester)
  • Average MAP >90 mmHg

Predictors no longer used include:

  • Hemoconcentration
  • Elevated fibronectin
  • Increase in uric acid levels
  • Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h
  • Increased homocysteine levels
  • Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent drug to control PPH?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is the most potent drug to control PPH.

Though oxytocin is the most commonly used drug for the prevention and treatment of PPH, Carboprost is highly efficacious than oxytocin in treating PPH. If the question would have been "Drug of choice to treat PPH" then the answer will be Oxytocin.

Misoprostol(PGE1)

2nd line drug to treat PPH

Initially for PPH, oxytocin or methergin (ergometrine) is given. If it fails to control the bleeding then Misoprostol is given.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: Given below is the hysterosalpingogram of a woman who presented with infertility. Identify the uterine anomaly seen.
questions.solution:
In a hysterosalpingogram, the uterine anomaly cannot be determined as the external contour of the uterus cannot be seen. 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity. However, it doesn't show the external contour, so it cannot distinguish between uterine anomalies such as didelphys, bicornuate, septate or arcuate uteruses.

Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV-US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation of uterine anomalies. It is the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV-US is not possible.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginal mucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella. 

Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue cells are visible.

Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present. 

Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white.

Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. Which of the following is not included in this condition?
questions.solution:
Cervicitis is not included in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Pelvic inflammatory disease is a spectrum of infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, typically causing:

  • Endometritis
  • Salpingitis
  • Oophoritis
  • Peritonitis

The minimum criteria for diagnosis of PID are:

Pain in the lower abdomen + any one of the following:

  • Uterine tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness

Cervicitis and vaginitis are lower genital tract infections.

questions.text: What is the most common mode of transmission of tuberculosis to the endometrium?
questions.solution:
Endometrial tuberculosis is most commonly acquired by direct spread from the fallopian tubes. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct extension.

Female genital tuberculosis is an important cause of significant morbidity, short and long-term sequelae especially infertility. Genital tuberculosis usually occurs secondary to pulmonary (commonest) or extrapulmonary TB like gastrointestinal, renal, skeletal, and miliary TB. However, primary genital TB can rarely occur in women whose male partners have active genitourinary TB (e.g., tuberculosis epididymitis) by transmission through infected semen

Most common site involved in secondary genital TB is fallopian tube (90-100%) >endometrium (50-80%) >ovaries (20-30%)  >cervix 5-15%) >vulva. The most common symptom of genital TB is infertility.

Causes of infertility in genital TB:

  • Tubal blockage
  • If tubes are patent, then also infertility occurs due to loss of tubal function.
  • Tubercular endometritis causes uterine scarring resulting in the destruction of the endometrium.
  • Ovarian damage with poor ovarian reserve and volume

A laparoscopy and dye hydrotubation (lap and dye test) is the most reliable tool to diagnose genital TB, especially for tubal, ovarian and peritoneal disease. The test can be combined with hysteroscopy.

Multiple drug therapy ( ATT regimen provided by DOTS) in adequate doses and for sufficient duration is the mainstay in the treatment of TB including genital tuberculosis.

questions.text: A woman with urinary incontinence was diagnosed to have a vesicovaginal fistula. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Vesicovaginal fistulas are mostly acquired. 

In developing countries, the most common cause is obstetric trauma. In developed countries, iatrogenic injury during pelvic surgery is responsible for 90% of the vesicovaginal fistulas. 

Congenital genitourinary fistulas and fistulas resulting from infectious conditions are rare.

questions.text: A young mother presented with dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. Marshall and Bonney's test was positive. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is conservative management.

Stress incontinence is managed as follows:

Conservative management:

  • It is the first line of treatment.
  • It includes:
    • Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months
    • Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation
    • Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition
    • Vaginal cones
  • It is also done in case surgery fails. 

Medical management:

  • Estrogen cream in menopausal woman
  • Venlafaxine 75 mg daily
  • Imipramine 10–20 mg BD

Surgical management:

  • Kelly's repair - vaginal approach
  • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
  • Burch colposuspension
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
  • Slings
    • Tension-free vaginal taping
    • Transobturator taping
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection 

Vaginal sling operations have the highest long term cure rate in cases of GSI (genuine stress incontinence). Their long term cure rate is more than 90%.

questions.text: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.solution:
The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for iatrogenic causes.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum.

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: When should fibroids in pregnancy be operated?
questions.solution:
• During pregnancy, surgery is contraindicated, except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid if it undergoes torsion.
  • Similarly, myomectomy is not advisable during caesarean section, because of the uncontrolled bleeding that may ensure, except for a pedunculated fibroid.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.

Grading of ovarian cancer:

  • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
  • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. 
  • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur. 

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the Cervarix vaccine?
questions.solution:
The Cervarix vaccine is not protective against genital warts. It is mainly protective against CIN and cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with dyspareunia due to scarring secondary to perineal tears from previous vaginal delivery. The gynaecologist advises the use of the following dilator to widen the introitus. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Fenton dilator. These can be identified by the neck/notch at the centre.

Fenton's or modified Fenton's procedure is performed to widen the introitus in women with superficial dyspareunia secondary to scarring. The narrowing of introitus could be due to scarring secondary to perineal tears during childbirth or from conditions such as lichen sclerosus or vestibulitis.

Fenton dilators come in sizes numbered from 3-10 and the sizes of the dilators range from 3mm to 26mm.

Option B: Hawkins dilator is single-ended.

Options A and C: Hegar and Pratt dilators are also double-ended dilators but they do not have a notch at the centre. Pratt dilator is more linear in appearance compared to Hegar dilator.

questions.text: A young lady who presented with oligomenorrhea and infertility is diagnosed with PCOS. Mutation of which of the following genes can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Mutation of the CYP21 gene can cause polycystic ovarian syndrome.

The gene for 21-hydroxylase (CYP21) is located in the short arm of chromosome 6. Heterozygosity of the gene has been linked to the development of PCOS. Defects in this gene also lead to congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

PCOS and PCOD are two different diseases. In PCOD, the ovaries begin to release immature eggs, resulting in hormonal imbalances and enlarged ovaries, whereas in PCOS, it is an endocrine disorder that causes the ovaries to create excess androgens, making the eggs prone to cyst formation. However, unlike with PCOD, these cysts will not be expelled and will instead accumulate in the ovaries.

questions.text: Vulvar carcinoma was diagnosed in a 68-year-old woman who presented with itching and mass over the vulva for 6 months. Sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed positive inguinal nodes. What is the stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of melanoma in this patient except?
questions.solution:
D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
Scarf sign is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below),

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include:

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include:

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Eye/ear
  4. Plantar crease 
  5. Breast
  6. Genitals

The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn by scoring six criteria and thereby calculating the gestational age. It is accurate between 20 to 44 weeks. 

The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age. An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age

Given in the image below is the scoring system for the physical and neuromuscular criteria:

questions.text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a term neonate?
questions.solution:
Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures in term babies. Seizures due to HIE typically appear within the first 12-24 hours of birth. Subtle seizures are the most common type of seizures in neonates with HIE. 

Neonatal seizures:

  • Most common type - Subtle seizures
  • Least common type - Myoclonic seizures
  • Most common metabolic cause - Hypoglycemia
  • Investigation of choice for the diagnosis of seizures - Electroencephalogram (EEG) 
  • Neuroimaging modality of choice for etiological evaluation - MRI
  • Drug of choice - Phenobarbitone

Most common cause of neonatal seizures in:

  • Term neonate - Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)
  • Preterm neonate - Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation?

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask  ventilation.
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.solution:
As per the newborn resuscitation protocol (NRP), a heart rate < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation is the indication to administer epinephrine.

The NRP algorithm is shown below:

The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate, as a rise in heart rate is the most effective indicator of successful ventilatory effort.

If the heart rate is less than 100, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is provided with a bag and mask. 

In case of no response even after doing ventilation corrective steps (Options C and D), endotracheal intubation is done.

The ventilation corrective steps are as follows and can be remembered with the mnemonic MRSOPA.

  1. Mask has to be reapplied 
  2. Reposition head
  3. Suction the secretions
  4. Open mouth slightly and ventilate
  5. Pressure is increased slightly
  6. Airway may be changed

If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3:1.

If the heart rate continues to remain <60 despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone
4 months Reaches out for objects with both hands (Bidextrous reach)
6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects
9 months Immature pincer grasp
12 months Mature pincer grasp
15 months Imitates scribbling and builds a tower of 2 blocks
18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks
2 years Builds a tower of 6 blocks
3 years Builds a tower of 9 blocks and copies a circle
4 years Builds a bridge with blocks and copies a cross
5 years Copies a triangle and builds a gate with blocks

questions.text: A child who was being evaluated for hypertyrosinemia is diagnosed with Richner-Hanhart syndrome. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the likely cause of hypertyrosinemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase.

It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability.Untreated patients have marked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal, as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone.

questions.text: A 3-hour-old neonate with apnea has been on bag and mask ventilation for the last 30 seconds. She has now started taking spontaneous breaths. The heart rate is still between 100 and 110/min. What is your next step?
questions.solution:
As per the NRP algorithm, at any time during resuscitation, if the HR > 100 and spontaneous breathing resumes then discontinue ventilation.
The components of NRP resuscitation include: (TABCD)

  • Temperature- maintain between 36.5 and 37.5 C
  • Airway- "sniffing" position, clear secretions if needed
  • Breathing- free flow O2 (maintain sats 91–95%), PPV (40–60 breaths /min), ETT
  • Circulation- chest compressions:ventilation ratio (3:1 = 90:30; lower 1/3rd sternum; two thumb technique preferred)
  • Drugs- Epinephrine, volume expanders 

Algorithm states:

  • HR < 100/min + no respirations →  Positive pressure ventilation (PPV)
  • No response with PPV → Endotracheal intubation (ET)
  • HR < 60/min → Chest compressions
  • No response to chest compressions → epinephrine

questions.text: What is the clinical procedure being performed?

choices.text: Femoral IV access for fluid transfusion

questions.solution:
The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. 

  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
  • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia.

Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion: 

  • In the proximal tibia, 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity
  • Distal tibia at the junction of the medial malleolus and the shaft of the tibia
  • Distal one-third of the femur

questions.text: As an obstetrician, you discover an atrial septal defect incidentally in a 20-year-old primigravida. You will be watchful about all of the following complications, except:
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis is extremely rare in isolated atrial septal defect (ASD) and antibiotic prophylaxis for isolated ASDs is not recommended. 

ASD is a low-pressure gradient defect whereas a high-pressure gradient across a defect is required to create a turbulent flow, which traumatizes the vascular endothelium, making the patient susceptible to endocarditis.

Patients with a small or moderate ASD are asymptomatic unless a complication occurs. Pulmonary hypertension, atrial dysrhythmias, tricuspid or mitral insufficiency, and heart failure may initially appear during the increased volume load of pregnancy.

questions.text: What test is being performed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the given image is diascopy.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colors to be evaluated.

Some uses of diascopy are as follows: 

  • Apple jelly nodules -  Yellow-brown lesions seen in lupus vulgaris and sarcoidosis.
  • Spider naevi - Compression of radiating arterioles is noted. 
  • Differentiation of erythema (disappears) and purpura (remains unaltered).

The image given below shows apple-jelly nodules on diascopy.

questions.text: A lady developed hypopigmentation on her forehead as shown below. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Crocein scarlet MOO and solvent yellow 3

questions.solution:
The lady has bindi leukoderma, which is caused by para-tertiary butyl-phenol (PTBP). It is present in adhesive sticker bindi.

This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact. 

There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit melanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with the tyrosinase enzyme.

Chemical leukoderma Causative chemicals
Bindi leukoderma Para-tertiary butyl-phenol (PTBP)
Synthetic leather, rubber slippers, latex condoms, rubber gloves

Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBH)-Rubber antioxidant
Hair dye p-Phenylenediamine (PPD)
Alta (red color like henna) Crocein scarlet MOO and solvent yellow 3 (azo dyes)

The image below shows synthetic leather-/rubber-related leucoderma.

 

The image below shows Alta depigmentation.

 

The image below shows hair dye depigmentation.

questions.text: While collecting data on nail changes in psoriasis patients, you note the following findings. Which of the following is the most specific finding for this condition?
questions.solution:
Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch (image C), a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil. The reddish-brown color is due to dilated, tortuous, superficial capillaries in the papillary dermis and parakeratosis.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: Which of the following is a subepidermal disease?
questions.solution:
Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal vesiculobullous disorder.

In bullous pemphigoid, there is subepidermal separation at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ). Eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltration are noted. It is not associated with acantholysis.

questions.text: Histopathology of a tissue sample from a patient with leprosy is shown below. Which form of the disease is this patient unlikely to have?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a grenz zone or Band of Unna, which is a band of uninvolved papillary dermis that does not contain granulomas or inflammatory infiltrate. It is absent in tuberculoid leprosy.

The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy, as there are scarce granulomas to fill up the space. It is also seen in the borderline spectrum.

In tuberculoid leprosy, dermal granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.  

The grenz zone is also seen in granuloma faciale and B-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with the following lesions over the chest. Identify the incorrect statement about the infection.

choices.text: Topical terbinafine is the first-line treatment
Besnier's sign is seen in this condition
Wood's lamp examination shows blue-green fluorescence
Recurrence is common even after complete treatment

questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple hypopigmented macules and patches with fine scales (branny/furfuraceous) suggestive of tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor).

Hypopigmentation is due to azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species that causes competitive inhibition of tyrosinase and a direct cytotoxic effect on hyperactive melanocytes.

Under Wood's lamp examination, lesions show a pale yellow fluorescence.  

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign or scratch sign or stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scales with a fingernail, which is called the scratch sign. The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk.

Relapse is very common.

First-line treatment: 

  • Topical azoles twice daily for 2–3 weeks 
  • Terbinafine 1% cream twice daily for 2–3 weeks
  • Ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for 2-3 weeks
  • 2.5% selenium shampoo alternative days for 2-3 weeks

 Second-line treatment: Oral itraconazole, 200 mg daily for 5 days

The image below shows the pale yellow fluorescence of Tinea versicolor under Wood's lamp. 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with painful deep ulcers on his penis as shown below. He also has painful unilateral lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with painful, deep ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy has chancroid. It is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

The incubation period is 3-10 days. The primary lesion begins as a painful papule that undergoes central necrosis to form painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges. Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present.

It is associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which later progresses to form suppurating buboes and sinuses.

Option B: HSV-2 infection presents with multiple vesicles, which develop into shallow ulcers, along with painful lymphadenopathy.

Option C: LGV presents with a painless or painful ulcer later followed by painful lymphadenopathy. The incubation period is 3-30 days.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale or donovanosis presents with a painless papule that forms a beefy red ulcer with no lymphadenopathy. The incubation period is 8-80 days (average 50 days).

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers
