questions.text: Which skin condition is shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
A typical coin lesion is shown which points to nummular dermatitis.

A solitary plaque with small vesicles can be seen.

The diagnostic lesion of nummular dermatitis is a well-demarcated coin-shaped erythematous plaque with vesicles surrounding it.

Other options:

Asteatotic eczema: Develops in very dry skin, has a crazy paving pattern appearance

Berloque dermatitis: Not necessarily discoid in shape. Present along the area of spraying and dripping of perfume.

Atopic Eczema: Presents as an itchy rash. Not necessarily discoid in shape.

questions.text: A student applied to four national universities for her MBA course but was disheartened when she got rejected from all four universities. While talking to her friend on the phone, she said she never wanted to go anyway because they were too far from home. What defense mechanism is being used by her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario point towards rationalization. The student is rationalizing her rejection by saying she wouldn't have gone even if she got accepted because of the distance from home.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: The memory disorder correctly matched with the pathology is?

choices.text: Korsakoff syndrome -  hyperactivation of mammillary bodies
Alzheimer's disease - early degeneration of frontal lobe
Frontotemporal dementia - mesial temporal lobe atrophy

questions.solution:
The cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease is due to the loss of synapses and neuronal degeneration.

Microscopically, the following are seen:

  • Neuritic plaques - containing amyloid-β
  • Neurofibrillary tangles - containing abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins
  • Amyloid-β accumulation in the blood vessel walls of the cortex and leptomeninges.

Option A: In Korsakoff syndrome, there is inactivation (not hyperactivation) of mammillary bodies due to thiamine deficiency.

Option C: Alzheimer's disease initially affects the parietal and temporal lobe, followed by the frontal lobe in the later stages. Hence personality changes are a late feature of Alzheimer's. 

Option D: Mesial temporal lobe atrophy is very sensitive to Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: As part of a psychiatric evaluation, you ask the patient about what he would do if he suddenly sees a house on fire. What is being assessed here?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, test judgment is being assessed. Judgment is the ability to assess a situation, make good decisions, and act on them. 

Test judgment is assessed by asking the patient what he would do in hypothetical situations, such as a house on fire, or a man lying on the road, or a sealed, stamped, addressed envelope lying on a street.

Social judgment is the ability to perceive social situations and act accordingly. The following are observed during the hospital stay and during the interview session:

  • Does the patient understand the likely outcome of personal behavior?
  • Subtle manifestations of behavior that are harmful to the patient.
  • Behavior that is not culturally acceptable.

There is no category called response judgment.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. This effect is due to its action on which dopaminergic pathway?
questions.solution:
Antipsychotic drugs act on the mesolimbic pathway to reduce positive symptoms of schizophrenia such as hallucinations and delusions.

The drug Lumateperone, an atypical anti-psychotic was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of schizophrenia in adults.

Related Pearl: Actions of antipsychotic drugs

Dopaminergic pathway Significance Action of drug blocking D2 receptors
Nigrostriatal Movement Extrapyramidal symptoms
Mesolimbic Speech, grasp of reality, mentation, and mood Reduces positive symptoms of schizophrenia
Mesocortical Motivation, pleasure, socialization May increase negative symptoms of schizophrenia
Tuberoinfundibular pathway Inhibits prolactin release Hyperprolactinemia
Chemoreceptor trigger zone Vomiting reflex Anti emetic

questions.text: An adolescent boy with schizophrenia had witnessed his parents fighting with each other for the past several years. He is overly close with his mother and she convinced him to take her side in the divorce. He always blamed his father for all their family problems. Which of the following best describes the abnormal family dynamics?
questions.solution:
This scenario describes an abnormal family dynamic, where one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender. This is known as marital schism.

Marital schism, marital skew, expressed emotions, and double-bind refer to abnormalities of family dynamics. They act as psychosocial stressors, hampering the adaptive capacity of the individual, thus contributing to the development of schizophrenia.

Marital schism- one parent is overly close to the child of the opposite gender.

Marital skew- a disharmonious situation where one parent dominates over the other.

Expressed emotions- parents or other caregivers may behave with overt criticism, hostility, or over-involvement towards a person with schizophrenia, which further worsens the illness.

Double bind- a hypothetical family in which children receive conflicting parental messages about their behavior, attitudes, and feelings.

questions.text: Otto veraguth fold is seen in ______
questions.solution: Otto Veraguth fold is a physical sign of depression wherein there is a triangular fold in the nasal corner of upper eyelid.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man who came to the dermatology clinic for acne complaints was incidentally noted to have multiple scars suspected to be from 'skin popping'. He is most likely to be abusing which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, opioid abuse is the most likely cause of the skin popping scars in this patient. Skin popping is a method of injecting illicit drugs into the skin. Drugs like heroin, cocaine, barbiturates can be injected intradermally or subcutaneously with the goal of achieving slower absorption, decreased risk of overdose, and easier administration than with intravenous drug use.

LSD and mescaline (hallucinogens) and cannabis are not taken through injections, but by oral route or through smoking.

The image given below shows circular depressed scars from skin popping.

questions.text:
A distressed 22-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of frequent checking the doors even when they are locked. He is subsequently diagnosed to have obsessive-compulsive disorder. Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Undoing, reaction formation, and isolation are the defence mechanisms involved
  2. Clomipramine is the drug of choice
  3. Risperidone may be used in SSRI resistant cases to augment the response
  4. Systematic desensitisation is the psychotherapy of choice
  5. Temporal lobectomy is a common psychosurgical option
questions.solution:
Undoing, reaction formation, and isolation are the defence mechanisms involved in OCD. Antipsychotics such as risperidone and aripiprazole can be used in SSRI-resistant cases to augment the response.

Statement 2: SSRI is the drug of choice in OCD. Clomipramine is the first FDA-approved agent for the treatment of OCD. In case of failure of 2 SSRIs, clomipramine is indicated.

Statement 4: Exposure and response prevention is the psychotherapy of choice for OCD

Statement 5: Temporal lobectomy is a common treatment option for temporal lobe epilepsy resistant to anticonvulsants (and not in OCD). 

Non-pharmacological treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder:

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning
  • Psychotherapy
  • Electroconvulsive therapy
  • Psychosurgery
    • Ablative: Cingulotomy, Subcaudate tractotomy
    • Non-Ablative: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought by his mother who says that over the past year her son has started staying in his room all day reading about paranormal phenomena and demons. He has no hallucinations, no friends, and no interest in his college work or interacting with family members. On examination, he talks about how aliens live among us despite having never actually seen them.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the patient's odd and eccentric beliefs and magical thinking is suggestive of Schizotypal personality disorder. Excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

Schizotypal personality disorder commonly progresses to schizophrenia. Some patients, however, maintain a stable schizotypal personality throughout their lives.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was rushed to the ER with chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. On examination, her respiratory rate was 32/min, and carpopedal spasm was noted while measuring BP. Her ECG was normal. Which of the following acid-base disorders is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. The patient is likely to have respiratory alkalosis. 

Panic attacks are characterized by hyperventilation which leads to a washout of CO2 (reduced PaCO2). This further increases the ratio of bicarbonate concentration to PaCO2 and, thereby, increases the pH level causing alkalosis. 

Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium in the blood. This leads to hypocalcemia without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm, especially in calcium-deficient patients. 

Induction of carpopedal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for three minutes or more is called Trousseau sign. It is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia. 

Causes of respiratory alkalosis:

  • Central nervous system stimulation:
    • Pain
    • Anxiety, psychosis
    • Fever
    • Cerebrovascular accident
    • meningitis, encephalitis
    • Tumor
    • Trauma
  • Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia:
    • High altitude
    • Pneumonia, pulmonary edema
    • Aspiration
    • Severe anemia
  • Drugs or hormones:
    • Pregnancy
    • Salicylates
    • Cardiac failure
  • Stimulation of chest receptors:
    • Hemothorax
    • Flail chest
    • Cardiac failure
    • Pulmonary embolism
  • Miscellaneous:
    • Septicemia
    • Hepatic failure
    • Mechanical hyperventilation
    • Heat exposure
    • Recovery from metabolic acidosis

Note: While metabolic alkalosis can also cause hypocalcemia, the above scenario of hyperventilation is more suggestive of respiratory alkalosis. Furthermore, hypocalcemic symptoms are more common with respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Diagnostic criteria for RVH:

  • Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1).
  • Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1).
  • Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more.

For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used.

It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).

questions.text: Which among the following is not a component of CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
Age > 60 years is not a component of the CHADS2-VASc score. Age > 75years and age group 65-75 yrs are the two age criteria considered in the score.

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients who have atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation therapy is given when the score is ≥2. Patients with a score of 1 may also be considered for anticoagulation therapy.

Anticoagulation therapy is given for all the patients of AF having mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or a history of stroke.

questions.text: The severity of mitral regurgitation can be judged by ______
questions.solution:
Presence of left ventricular S3 suggests severe mitral regurgitation.

In chronic severe mitral regurgitation, the following features are seen:

  • Left ventricular S3- due to the sudden tensing of papillary muscles, chordae tendinae and valve leaflets.
  • Holosystolic murmur-of grade III/IV. It is most prominent at the apex and radiates to the axilla.
  • Wide split S2- due to early closure of aortic valve.

questions.text: Which of the following pathological lesion is seen in infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Bracht-Wachter bodies are seen in infective endocarditis.

Pathologic Bodies Description 
Brancht-Wachter bodies

These are yellow-white spots found in the myocardium in patients with infective endocarditis.

Histologically, they are collections of chronic inflammatory cells, mainy lymphoctes and histiocytes.
Birbeck bodies These granules are shaped like rods or tennis racket with a central linear density and a striated appeareance. They are characteristics of langerhans cell hiscytosis (Histiocytosis X).
Civatte bodies Spherical, eosinophilic hyaline bodies seen in or below the epidermis in the disease lichen planus. Also called colloid bodies, they are formed by necrosis of individual basal cells.
Guarnieri bodies Round or oval cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in patients with smallpox. They are slightly basophilic or acidophilic and lie close to nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in patients with COPD?
questions.solution:
Clubbing is not a sign of COPD. Its presence should trigger the investigation of the causes of clubbing, particularly lung cancer.

Signs of COPD:

  • Signs of respiratory distress
    • Tripod posture - facilitates the use of accessory muscles of respiration
    • Pursed lip breathing - seen in emphysema
    • Central cyanosis
  • Signs of cachexia
    • Severe weight loss
    • Bitemporal wasting
  • Signs of hypercapnia (type 2 respiratory failure) - more common in chronic bronchitis
  • Barrel-shaped chest - increase in the anteroposterior diameter
  • Enlarged lung volumes
  • Positive Hoover's sign - paradoxical inward movement of the chest during inspiration
  • Early inspiratory coarse crackles  
  • Normal vesicular breath sounds of reduced-intensity with bilaterally prolonged expiration
  • Blue bloaters - cyanotic (blue) and edematous (bloaters), chronic bronchitis predominant features
  • Pink puffers - thin, non-cyanotic (pink) at rest, and severely dyspneic (puffers), emphysema predominant features 

Causes of clubbing:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Chronic interstitial pneumonitis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
  • Gastrointestinal 
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Sprue
    • Neoplasms - esophagus, liver, bowel
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism (Grave’s disease)

The image below shows the characteristic tripod posture in a patient with COPD.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male HIV patient presents to the ED with a cough with bloody sputum. He also has night sweats, chills, and difficulty in breathing. A chest X-ray and examination of the sputum show the following findings. Which of the following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray and gram-staining is suggestive of Nocardiosis. The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole.

Nocardia is a gram-positive and acid-fast bacteria. Nocardia pneumonia has a sub-acute presentation with mostly cough with thick sputum and fever. Generally, hemoptysis is uncommon. Chest radiography shows nodular infiltrations involving bilateral lung fields.

Extrapulmonary manifestations are common, the brain is the most commonly involved organ. It is associated with dense bilateral infiltrates with cavitating nodules and subacute brain abscesses.

The drug of choice is cotrimoxazole. Severe disease is treated with a combination of cotrimoxazole, amikacin, and ceftriaxone, or imipenem.

Note: Mnemonic SNAP: 

Sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim (Cotrimoxazole) is the drug of choice for Nocardia.

For Actinomyces, Penicillins are the drugs of choice.

questions.text: Patients with CKD have increased levels of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Serum estrogen levels are low in CKD patients. This leads to menstrual abnormalities and infertility. 

Option A: Plasma levels of insulin are elevated in CKD patients due to impaired clearance by the affected kidneys. Hence, insulin dose must be reduced in these patients.

Option B: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels in CKD are secondary to derangements in the homeostasis of calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D.

Option D: FGF-23 (fibroblast growth factor) is part of a family of phosphatonins that promotes renal phosphate excretion. The levels of this hormone increase early in the course of CKD.

questions.text: What acid-base disturbance is seen in patients with renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap  hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis.

questions.solution:
In renal tubular acidosis (RTA), there is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contradiction to the use of rtPA?
questions.solution:
Platelets < 200,000 is not a contraindication to recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA). 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of lower extremity weakness. He initially noticed difficulty climbing the stairs and now he is unable to stand. He gives a history of bloody diarrhea a few weeks ago. Which of the following parameters are expected to be elevated in the CSF of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). Protein levels are elevated (100-1000mg/dl) in the CSF of a patient with this condition.

The CSF cell counts are usually normal. Albuminocytologic dissociation, which is an elevation in CSF protein without an elevation in white blood cells, is characteristic in GBS.

Causes of albuminocytologic dissociation are:

  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumours

questions.text: A patient with weakness of the limbs and reduced vision, after evaluation, was diagnosed to be a case of multiple sclerosis. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
HLA-DRB1 is a risk factor for the development of multiple sclerosis, not HLA-B27.

Risk factors supporting the course of development of multiple sclerosis include:

  • Cigarette smoking
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Family history, HLA-DRB1
  • Exposure to Epstein-Barr virus (Human Herpesvirus 4) after early childhood

questions.text: What is the use of MIDAS questionnaire?

choices.text: To help decide treatment of migraine

questions.solution:
The Migraine Disability Assessment Score (MIDAS) questionnaire was put together to help measure the impact of migraine on patients' lives.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is referred to your centre for evaluation of short stature. The child's parents are found to be first cousins. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of Laron-type dwarfism. What causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-receptor anomalies.

Laron-type dwarfism is an autosomal recessive disorder. The primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. Treatment is by subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.

questions.text: Which of the following catecholamines would be elevated in a patient with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine is exclusively secreted in patients with extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma.

The PNMT (phenylethanolamine-N-methyl transferase) enzyme converts norepinephrine to epinephrine. This enzyme is absent in extra-adrenal sites. Hence, extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas secrete only norepinephrine and cannot secrete epinephrine. 

On the other hand, adrenal pheochromocytomas can secrete norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine in varying amounts depending on the PNMT levels in the tumor.

Extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas or catecholamine-secreting paragangliomas are most commonly found in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl.

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity and irritability are considered as the most common symptoms of thyrotoxicosis.

The following table summarizes the symptoms and signs of thyrotoxicosis in descending order of frequency:

Symptoms Signs
  • Hyperactivity, irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhoea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea, loss of libido
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goitre
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia

Rarely, there can be an associated mid-systolic heart murmur called the Means-Lerman scratch. This is heard in the upper part of the sternum caused by the rubbing of the pericardium and the pleura, due to the hyperdynamic circulation.

questions.text: A patient is said to have developed insulin resistance when the required insulin dosage is which of the following?
questions.solution:
When a patient needs > 200 units of insulin per day, they are said to have developed insulin resistance.

Some causes of insulin resistance are as follows:

  • Werner syndrome
  • Lipodystrophy syndrome
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Polycystic ovarian disease

Insulin resistance can present as non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with fatigue, pruritis, and xanthomas over the elbows. A biopsy of her bile duct revealed florid duct lesions. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Florid duct lesion is characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). It is the lymphocytes and plasma cells all centered around bile ducts. 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis has the characteristic  "onion-skin" concentric fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts.

questions.text: What pattern of gastritis is most common in patients with H.pylori-related duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Antral predominant gastritis is associated with duodenal ulcers. Antral predominant gastritis is associated with increased acid production by the parietal cells. This subjects the duodenum to increased acid exposure, leading to the formation of duodenal ulcers.

H. pylori infection may result in the following patterns of gastritis:

  • Non-atrophic pangastritis- mostly asymptomatic and sometimes associated with MALToma.
  • Corpus predominant gastritis- affects the corpus and causes atrophy. This leads to the loss of acid-producing parietal cells that are primarily found in the corpus. Hence, it is associated with decreased acid production. This is also a predisposing factor for the development of gastric cancer.
  • Antral predominant gastritis- spares the parietal cells. Hence, it is associated with increased acid production.

Option A: Autoimmune gastritis is caused due to autoantibodies against the parietal cells. It is not associated with H. pylori.

Option C: Granulomatous gastritis is characterized by the presence of granulomas It is associated with Crohn's disease and sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented with hematuria and dysuria for 5 days. He also complains of chronic diarrhea and weight loss for 6 months. His urine microscopy revealed the following stones. What is the most likely disorder associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The given urinary crystal is the bipyramidal or envelope-shaped crystals of calcium oxalate dihydrate. Calcium oxalate stones are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease.

In Crohn's disease (especially post small bowel resection), fatty acids are not absorbed because of ileal dysfunction. These fatty acids in the gut lumen bind to calcium. Because of this, the dietary oxalates which normally bind to the calcium are now left unbound. This leads to increased absorption of dietary oxalates leading to hyperoxaluria and oxalate stones.

Note: Celiac disease is also associated with calcium oxalate stones.

questions.text: The Anti-myeloperoxidase antibody is seen in all except
questions.solution:
The Anti-myeloperoxidase antibody is not seen in Henoch Schonlein Purpura.

Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies(pANCA) are typically seen in Microscopic polyangiitis. It can also be seen in:

  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss)
  • Isolated necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s)
  • Drug-induced vasculitis (Hydralazine and propylthiouracil).

Note: In Wegener's granulomatosis, >90% of patients have positive anti proteinase cANCA, however, a small percentage of patients can have positive anti myeloperoxidase pANCA.

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: What is the most common type of leukemia in adults?
questions.solution:
Chronic lymphoid leukemia (CLL) is the most common type of leukemia in adults.

The common types of leukemia in various age groups is as follows:

  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) - most common acute leukemia in adults
  • Acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) - most common cancer in childhood. The most common subtype of ALL is B-cell ALL
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) - most common lymphoid malignancy in adults

questions.text: What is the most common cause of renal failure in patients with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is the most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma.

The second most common cause of renal failure in multiple myeloma is light chain cast nephropathy. The most common type of myeloma causing renal failure is light chain myeloma. 

Mechanisms involved in acute kidney injury are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Amyloid deposits
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Recurrent infections
  • Infiltration of the kidney by myeloma cells
  • Tubular damage by excretion of light chains (Fanconi's syndrome)

questions.text: A patient with dizziness and breathing difficulty came to the emergency department. The ECG is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms suggests a likely diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

Electrical alternans is the beat-to-beat alternation in the ECG waveform. In cardiac tamponade, this is caused by the periodic swinging motion of the heart in a large pericardial effusion.

questions.text: Which of the following case scenarios depict a mode of transmission that carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV?

choices.text: A 23-year-old drug addict sharing syringes during intravenous drug abuse
A 15-year-old thalassemic adolescent undergoing blood transfusion
A 30-year-old man engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners
A 27-year-old nurse accidentally injuring herself while drawing blood

questions.solution:
Blood transfusion carries the highest risk of acquiring HIV.

Salient features of transmission of HIV:

  • The highest risk of acquiring HIV from an infected source is via blood transfusion > needle sharing during drug abuse > receptive anal intercourse > needle-stick injury > vaginal & oral sexual intercourse.
  • The most common mode of transmission worldwide is sexual transmission (heterosexual in India) > mother to child > least common modes are blood transfusion & needle-stick injury.
  • Male to female transmission > female to male transmission.
  • Viral load is highest in blood > semen > vaginal fluid > breastmilk & saliva and minimal to absent in tears, sweat & urine.

questions.text: The most common  cause of Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in developing countries:
questions.solution:
The most common cause of HUS in developing countries is Shigella dysenteriae and the most common cause of HUS in developed countries-EHEC  0157 H7.

Other cause of HUS:

Infection:

  • Streptococcus pneumonia 
  • Salmonella 
  • Campylobacter
  • Influenza virus 
  • Varicella virus
  • Epstein barr virus

Drugs:

  • Oral contraceptives
  • Cyclosporin 

Familial

questions.text: Identify the vessel marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the MR angiography of cerebral circulation. The structure marked is the anterior cerebral artery which is a branch of the internal carotid artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A young male presents with pain in his right shoulder. He slipped during his treadmill workout and tried to hold on to the side rails. The x-ray image obtained is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient who developed pain in his shoulder after forced abduction of his shoulder after a fall. The x-ray shows the head of the humerus is below the glenoid and the shaft in the abducted position. This is suggestive of an inferior shoulder dislocation, also known as luxatio erecta. 

It is rare and occurs when the arm is forcefully pulled up when in full abduction (hyper-abduction force) due to high-energy trauma. The patient will present with the arm locked in almost full abduction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of fever and chest pain for the last 7 days. A chest X-ray was done. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and X-ray is suggestive of loculated pleural effusion.

The chest X-ray shows obliteration of right costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung. It tracks along the costphrenic angle and lateral chest wall.

A pleural lesion can be differentiated from a parenchymal lesion by the angle it makes with the chest wall. Pleural lesions makes an obtuse angle with the chest wall whereas a parenchymal lesions makes an acute angle with the chest wall.

questions.text:
The IVP of a patient with persistent flank pain is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?

IVP- Intravenous Pyelogram
questions.solution:
The given IVP in a patient with persistent flank pain shows the medial deviation of bilateral ureters, caused by fibrous tissue deposition in the retroperitoneum at the lumbosacral junction, resulting in the characteristic narrow-waisted maiden appearance, known as the maiden waist sign, which is seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPF) is a chronic, nonspecific inflammatory process of the fibro-fatty tissue in the retroperitoneum, with the idiopathic type being the most common, accounting for about 70% of the cases. Patients typically present with persistent flank pain or back pain. Progressive fibrotic thickening can compress the ureters, leading to bilateral hydronephrosis and, if untreated, renal failure. Aside from idiopathic causes, other causes of RPF include drug-induced factors ( e.g., methysergide, beta-blockers), advanced malignancy, radiation exposure, trauma, and chronic infections.

Diagnosis of RPF relies primarily on imaging studies. Intravenous urography shows a characteristic triad of medial deviation of the middle one-third of the ureters, producing a maiden waist sign, hydroureteronephrosis, and extrinsic compression of the ureters by the fibrotic process. CT and MRI are also useful in radiographic evaluation of RPF.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 1-month-old male infant is brought to the OPD with vomiting. History suggests a usage of maternal erythromycin. A USG abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG showing cervix sign and nipple sign is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Maternal intake of macrolide antibiotics during pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) in infants.

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The characteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. The following findings may be seen:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to casualty after falling from a balcony. Based on the CT scan finding provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above axial CT shows a hyperdense lentiform (biconvex) opacity, consistent with an epidural hematoma, which is a collection of blood between the inner surface of the skull and the outer periosteal layer of the dura mater, typically following a history of trauma. The characteristic biconvex shape arises due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of periosteal dura to the cranial sutures. If bleeding is significant, it may lead to a mass effect with herniation. 

Additionally, a swirl sign may be present, representing acute blood extravasation into a hematoma (extradural/subdural), showing fresh, unclotted blood with lower attenuation than the clotted blood (which is of a higher attenuation), highlighting the need for surgical intervention.

The following CT image depicts a swirl sign:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: What is the most common radiation used in radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
X-rays are the most common form of radiation used in radiotherapy. They are produced from LINAC (Linear Accelerator).

If X-rays are not among the options, the second best answer would be gamma rays.

Note: Sources of radiation exposure:

  • Natural: Cosmic rays, environmental (terrestrial and atmospheric), and radioactive isotopes - of potassium (K-40) and carbon (C-14).
  • Man-made: Medical and dental (X-rays, radioisotopes), occupational exposure and nuclear (radioactive fallout).

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle of PET scan?
questions.solution:
PET scans are based on the principle of production of a dual photon peak at 511 keV.

To perform a PET scan, a radionuclide tracer (labeled to FDG molecules) is used. These molecules decay in the body with the release of a positron. The positron travels a short distance and annihilates with an anti-particle (electron). This annihilation reaction results in the formation of two high-energy photons that travel in opposite directions. Each photon has an energy of 511 keV, making this a dual photon peak at 511 keV.

questions.text: Which is the most common fracture associated with acute compartment syndrome in adult patients?
questions.solution:
The most common fracture causing acute compartment syndrome in adult patients is tibial diaphyseal fractures.

Fractures are the most common cause for acute compartment syndrome. The top 3 fracture sites associated with acute compartment syndrome include:

  • Tibial diaphysis (shaft) 
  • Distal radius
  • Forearm bones diaphysis

Soft tissue injury is the second most common cause of acute compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of elbow dislocation?
questions.solution:
Posterior dislocations are the commonest type of elbow dislocation.

Elbow joint is the most common joint to dislocate in children. They usually result from a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension. It may be associated with soft tissue injury involving the brachial artery, ulnar, median, and radial nerve.

These dislocations occur with a progression from lateral to the medial side, termed as Hori’s circle. Complete dislocation is usually associated with disruption of the medial and lateral collateral ligaments and anterior capsule.

Patients present with severe pain at the elbow, and with the elbow in flexion. The three bony points relationship is disturbed. The triceps tendon becomes prominent (bowstringing of triceps). 

Reduction is done under anesthesia followed by immobilization in an above-elbow plaster slab for 3 weeks.

Related Pearl: Common dislocations at different joints

 Common dislocation at different joints
Shoulder Anterior 
Elbow Posterior and posterolateral
Wrist Lunate
Spine Cervical Spine (anterior C5 over C6)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man working as a clerk in an office presents with the following lesion in his elbow. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of olecranon bursitis. It is also known as Draughtman's elbow/student's elbow/ miner's elbow.

Olecranon bursitis is a chronic inflammation of the olecranon bursa, as a result of repetitive minor injuries. It is seen in people who tend to keep their elbow rubbed against the desk. The constant friction against the olecranon bursa can lead to the development of bursitis.

Culture and aspiration of the bursa fluid are done to rule out infection. Most cases can be managed conservatively with NSAIDs and local steroids. A chronically enlarged bursa will require excision.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow

Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament

questions.text: The prominence of two or three spinous processes is called:
questions.solution:
There are three types of kyphotic deformities which result due to tuberculosis

  • Knuckle - Prominence of one spinous process
  • Gibbus - Prominence of two or three spinous processes
  • Kyphus - Diffuse rounding of the vertebral column

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant was brought to the clinic with the given malformation present since birth. What is the primary deformity in this condition?
questions.solution:
Adduction of the forefoot is a primary deformity in congenital talipes equinus varus (CTEV). 

The five primary deformities in CTEV are:

  1. Cavus- excessive arching of the foot
  2. Adduction of forefoot
  3. Varus- inversion and adduction of foot 
  4. Equinus- increased plantar flexion 
  5. Internal tibial torsion- medial rotation of the tibia

questions.text: Which of the following structures will not be visualised in the X-ray of a patient with posterior hip dislocation?
questions.solution:
In posterior dislocation of the hip, the lesser trochanter is not visualized in the radiograph. This is due to the internal rotation of the limb.

In posterior dislocation of the hip, there is disruption of Shenton line. It is an imaginary curved line drawn along the inferior border of the superior pubic ramus and along the inferomedial border of the neck of femur. This line is continuous and smooth.

It is usually disrupted in:

  • Dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip

The image given below shows posterior dislocation with disruption of Shenton's line.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to the ER with complaints of chest pain. He suddenly collapsed and became unresponsive. His pulse was not recordable so you started chest compressions. Which of the following steps would you not perform according to the BLS algorithm?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway and other supraglottic airway devices are part of advanced airway management, which is included in advanced cardiac life support (ACLS).

Basic life support refers to the emergency management of sudden cardiac arrest, heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction, usually without the use of equipment other than automated external defibrillators.

The CPR sequence is as follows - circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing:

  • Circulation:
    • Chest compressions lead to ejection of blood from the heart, as a result of actual compression of the heart between the sternum and vertebral column.
  • Airway:
    • Head tilt, chin lift, and jaw thrust maneuvers are used to open the airway.
  • Breathing:
    • If there is no adequate breathing even after opening the airway, the rescuer should initiate assisted ventilation by giving rescue breaths to the patient using mouth-to-mouth, mouth-to-nose, mouth-to-stoma, mouth-to-barrier device, mouth-to-face shield, or mouth-to-mask rescue breathing or by using a bag-mask device.
  • Defibrillation:
    • Using automated external defibrillators (AED)

questions.text: Which drug stimulates the autonomic ganglia?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine stimulates the autonomic ganglia. 

  • Parasympathetic ganglion (vagal ganglion) - bradycardia
  • Sympathetic ganglion - hypertension and tachycardia.

Pancuronium causes tachycardia by blocking the cardiac muscarinic receptor and not by stimulation of autonomic ganglia.

D-tubocurarine blocks the autonomic ganglia. Whereas vercuronium does not act on autonomic ganglia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman is posted for resection of an intracranial tumor. Which inhalational anesthetic is most suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent of choice for neurosurgery in patients with elevated intracranial pressure (intracranial tumor) is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane best preserves the autoregulation of cerebral blood flow and produces limited vasodilatation. Hence, it is the preferred volatile agent in patients with elevated ICP.

The order of vasodilating potency is approximately : halothane > enflurane > desflurane > isoflurane > sevoflurane.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane

questions.text: For a patient with respiratory failure requiring controlled ventilation, which of the following is true about the order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits?
questions.solution:
From the above options, the order of efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is D=F>B>A. 

When the Mapleson D circuit is used for controlled ventilation, the fresh gas flow rate of the circuit is closest to the physiological minute ventilation of the patient.


 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: A middle-aged man with liver metastasis and altered LFT is posted for a surgery. What would be the opioid of choice in him?
questions.solution:
Opioid of choice in patients with compromised hepatic function is remifentanil.

Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases and hence its metabolism is independent of hepatic function.

Other opioids like fentanyl, alfentanil, and sufentanil are metabolized by the liver.
